title: Lowâcarbohydrate versus balancedâcarbohydrate diets for reducing weight and cardiovascular risk
abstract: Abstract Background Debates on effective and safe diets for managing obesity in adults are ongoing. Lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (also known as 'lowâcarb diets') continue to be widely promoted, marketed and commercialised as being more effective for weight loss, and healthier, than 'balanced'âcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets. Objectives To compare the effects of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets to weightâreducing diets with balanced ranges of carbohydrates, in relation to changes in weight and cardiovascular risk, in overweight and obese adults without and with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Search methods We searched MEDLINE (PubMed), Embase (Ovid), the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), Web of Science Core Collection (Clarivate Analytics), ClinicalTrials.gov and WHO International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (ICTRP) up to 25 June 2021, and screened reference lists of included trials and relevant systematic reviews.Â Language or publication restrictions were not applied. Selection criteria We included randomised controlled trials (RCTs) in adults (18 years+) who were overweight or living with obesity, without or with T2DM, and without or with cardiovascular conditions or risk factors. Trials had to compare lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets to balancedâcarbohydrate (45% to 65% of total energy (TE)) weightâreducing diets, have a weightâreducing phase of 2 weeks or longer and be explicitly implemented for the primary purpose of reducing weight, with or without advice to restrict energy intake.Â Data collection and analysis Two review authors independently screened titles and abstracts and fullâtext articles to determine eligibility; and independently extracted data, assessed risk of bias using RoB 2Â and assessed the certainty of the evidence using GRADE. We stratified analyses by participants without and with T2DM, and by diets with weightâreducing phases only and those with weightâreducing phases followed by weightâmaintenance phases. Primary outcomes were change in body weight (kg) and the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5%, assessed at shortâ (three months to < 12 months) and longâterm (â¥ 12 months) followâup. Main results We included 61 parallelâarm RCTs that randomised 6925 participants to either lowâcarbohydrate or balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets. All trialsÂ were conducted in highâincome countries except for oneÂ in China. Most participants (n = 5118 randomised) did not have T2DM. Mean baseline weight across trials was 95 kg (range 66 to 132 kg). Participants with T2DM were older (mean 57 years, range 50 to 65) than those without T2DM (mean 45 years, range 22 to 62). Most trials included men and women (42/61; 3/19 men only; 16/19 women only), and people without baseline cardiovascular conditions, risk factors or events (36/61). Mean baseline diastolic blood pressure (DBP) and lowâdensity lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol across trials were within normal ranges. The longest weightâreducing phase of diets was two years in participants without and with T2DM. Evidence from studies with weightâreducing phases followed by weightâmaintenance phases was limited. Most trials investigated lowâcarbohydrate diets (> 50 g to 150 g per day or < 45% of TE; n = 42), followed by very low (â¤ 50 g per day or < 10% of TE; n = 14), and then incremental increases from very low to low (n = 5). The most common diets compared were lowâcarbohydrate, balancedâfat (20 to 35% of TE) and highâprotein (> 20% of TE) treatment diets versus control diets balancedÂ for the three macronutrients (24/61). In most trials (45/61) the energy prescription or approach used to restrict energy intake was similar in both groups. We assessed the overall risk of bias of outcomes across trials as predominantly high, mostly from bias due to missing outcome data. Using GRADE, we assessed the certainty of evidence as moderate to very low across outcomes.Â Participants without and with T2DM lost weight when following weightâreducing phases of both diets at the short (range: 12.2 to 0.33 kg) and long term (range: 13.1 to 1.7 kg).Â In overweight and obese participants without T2DM: lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (weightâreducing phases only) probably result in little to no difference in change in body weight over three to 8.5 months (mean difference (MD) â1.07 kg, (95% confidence interval (CI) â1.55 to â0.59, I2 = 51%, 3286 participants, 37 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence) and over one to two years (MD â0.93 kg, 95% CI â1.81 to â0.04, I2 = 40%, 1805 participants, 14 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence); as well as change in DBP and LDL cholesterol over one to two years. The evidence is very uncertain about whether there is a difference in the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at one year (risk ratio (RR) 1.11, 95% CI 0.94 to 1.31, I2 = 17%, 137 participants, 2 RCTs,Â very lowâcertainty evidence).Â In overweight and obese participants with T2DM: lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (weightâreducing phases only) probably result in little to no difference in change in body weight over three to six months (MD â1.26 kg, 95% CI â2.44 to â0.09, I2Â = 47%, 1114 participants, 14 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence) and over one to two years (MD â0.33 kg, 95% CI â2.13 to 1.46, I2Â = 10%, 813 participants, 7 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence); as well in change in DBP, HbA1c and LDL cholesterol over 1 to 2 years. The evidence is very uncertain about whether there is a difference in the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at one to two years (RR 0.90, 95% CI 0.68 to 1.20, I2 =Â 0%, 106 participants, 2 RCTs,Â very lowâcertainty evidence).Â Evidence on participantâreported adverse effects was limited, and we could not draw any conclusions about these.Â Authors' conclusions There is probably little to no difference in weight reduction and changes in cardiovascular risk factors up to two years' followâup, when overweight and obese participants without and with T2DM are randomised to either lowâcarbohydrate or balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets.Â Plain language summary Lowâcarbohydrate diets or balancedâcarbohydrate diets: which works better for weight loss and heart disease risks?Â Key messages â¢ There is probably little to no difference in the weight lost by people following lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (also known as 'lowâcarb diets') compared to the weight lost by people following balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets, for up to two years. â¢ Similarly, there is probably little to no difference between the diets for changes in heart disease risks, like diastolic blood pressure, glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c, a measure of blood sugar levels over 2â3 months) and LDL cholesterol (âunhealthyâ cholesterol) up to two years. â¢ This was the case in people with and without type 2 diabetes. What are lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets? People spend lots of money on trying to lose weight using diets, products, foods and books, and continue to debate about which diets are effective and safe. So, examining the scientific evidence behind claims made is important. Lowâcarbohydrate diets are a broad category of weightâreducing diets that manipulate and restrict carbohydrates, protein and fat in diets. There are no consistent, widelyâaccepted definitions of these diets and different descriptions are used (such as, 'lowâcarbohydrate, highâproteinâ, 'lowâcarbohydrate, highâfat', or âvery lowâcarbohydrateâ). Lowâcarbohydrate diets are implemented in different ways, but they restrict grains, cereals and legumes, and other carbohydrateâcontaining foods; such as dairy, most fruit and certain vegetables. These foods are then typically replaced with foods higher in fat and protein; such as meats, eggs, cheese, butter, cream, oils. Some lowâcarbohydrate diets recommend eating as desired, while others recommend restricting the amount of energy eaten.Â Balancedâcarbohydrate diets contain more moderate amounts of carbohydrates, protein and fats, in line with current healthy eating advice from health authorities. When used for weight reduction, balanced diets recommend restricting the amount of energy eaten by guiding people to reduce their portion sizes and choose healthier foods (e.g. lean instead of fatty meat). Lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets are widely promoted, marketed and commercialised as being more effective for weight loss, and healthier, than 'balanced'âcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets. What did we want to find out? We wanted to find out if lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets were better for weight loss and heart disease risk factors than balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in adults who were overweight or living with obesity. We wanted to find this out for people with and without type 2 diabetes. What did we do?â¨We searched six electronic databases and trial registries for all trials* that compared lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in adults who were overweight or living with obesity. The trials had to last for at least three months. We compared and summarised the results of the trials and rated our confidence in the combined evidence, based on factors such as study methods and sizes.Â *A trial is a type of study in which participants are assigned randomly to two or more treatment groups. This is the best way to ensure similar groups of participants. What did we find? We found 61 trials involving 6925 people who were overweight or living with obesity. The biggest trial was in 419 people and the smallest was in 20 people. All except one of the trials were conducted in highâincome countries worldwide, and nearly half were undertaken in the USA (26). Most trials (36) were undertaken in people who did not have heart disease or risk factors. Most people (5118 people) did not have type 2 diabetes. The average starting weight of people across the trials was 95 kg. Most studies (37) lasted for six months or less; and the longest studies (6) lasted for two years. Main results Lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference in weight loss over the short term (trials lasting 3 to 8.5 months) and long term (trials lasting one to two years) compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets, in people with and without type 2 diabetes. In the short term, the average difference in weight loss was about 1 kg and in the long term, the average difference was less than 1 kg.Â People lost weight on both diets in some trials. The amount of weight lost on average varied greatly with both diets across the trials from less than 1 kg in some trials and up to about 12 kg in others in the short term and long term.Â Similarly, lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference in diastolic blood pressure, glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c) and LDL cholesterol (âunhealthyâ cholesterol) for up to two years.Â We could not draw any conclusions about unwanted effects reported by participants because very few trials reported these. What are the limitations of the evidence?Â We are moderately confident in the evidence. Our confidence was lowered mainly because of concerns about how some the trials were conducted, which included that many trials did not report all their results. Further research may change these results. How up to date is this evidence? The evidence is upâtoâdate to June 2021.

TABLE: a Serious risk of bias: All information is from a study at high overall risk of biasâ¨b Serious imprecision: OIS not metâ¨c Serious risk of bias: All information is from studies at high overall risk of biasâ¨d Serious risk of bias: All information is from a study that has some concerns for overall risk of biasâ¨e Very serious imprecision: OIS not met; 95% CI for the pooled estimate is consistent with the possibility for important harm and for important benefitâ¨f Serious risk of bias: All information is from studies at high risk or that have some concerns for overall risk of bias INTRO: Background INTRO: Description of the condition INTRO: The 2017 Global Nutrition Report estimates that two billion adults worldwide are overweight or obese, and 41 million children are overweight (Development Initiatives 2017). For the first time in history, more people globally are dying from the consequences of overeating than starvation and malnutrition (Forouzanfar 2015). This shift has happened in the last 20 to 30 years and is thought to be mainly due to diets that are of poor nutritional quality, high in energy density and often ultraâprocessed. Such diets often result in cumulative weight gain over time and consequently increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, stroke and some cancers (Forouzanfar 2015). Globalised food systems promote overâconsumption of these foods (Moubarac 2014;Â Swinburn 2011). INTRO: High body mass index (BMI) is an important modifiable risk factor for cardiovascular disease, diabetes, kidney diseases, certain cancers and musculoskeletal conditions (Berrington 2010;Â ERFC 2011;Â GBMRF for CD Collaboration 2014;Â Singh 2013;Â Whitlock 2009;Â Zheng 2011). The disease burdens related to obesity are particularly evident in lowâ and middleâincome countries. Cardiovascular disease deaths rose by 12.5% from 15.9 million in 2005 to 17.9 million in 2015, and lowâ and middleâincome countries accounted for over threeâquarters of these deaths (GBD MCDC 2016). In Africa, between 1980 and 2014, ageâstandardised prevalence of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) increased from 4.8% to 9.7% in men and from 7.7% to 12.6% in women (NCDâRisC 2017). These shifting disease patterns have a major impact on individual and family wellâbeing, and on economies, with large direct and indirect costs being associated with illness. INTRO: Description of the intervention INTRO: Pharmacotherapy, bariatric surgery and counselling that target diet, physical activity, and behaviour change are used to treat adult obesity (Dietz 2015). Due to the chronic and relapsing nature of obesity and its related conditions, current guidelines for the treatment of obesity recommend comprehensive management approaches that aim to achieve longâterm weight reduction. This includes intensive lifestyle intervention characterised by dietary restriction, increased physical activity, and behavioural management as firstâline treatment (Dietz 2015;Â Jensen 2014). Importantly, there is no 'oneâsizeâfitsâall' weightâreducing diet and different diets work for different people, based on preferences and ease of adherence (Jensen 2014;Â Johnston 2014). INTRO: The public, families and health professionals face an often dizzying array of weightâreducing diets, many of which have been commercialised as books, seminars, diet food products, supplements and other related products. These include, but are not limited to, various versions of lowâcarbohydrate diets (for example, Atkins diet (Atkins 1999)), lowâfat or soâcalled 'balanced diets', very lowâfat diets (for example, Ornish diet (Ornish 2001)), and lowâglycaemic diets (for example, South Beach diet (Agatston 2003)). INTRO: Nutrients are needed by the body in small (i.e. micronutrients such as vitamins and minerals) or large amounts (i.e. macronutrients) for growth, repair and optimal functioning (Lichtenstein 2005). Total daily energy intake is made up of the sum of the energy provided by the three macronutrients (i.e. carbohydrate, protein and fat). Per gram of macronutrient, carbohydrates and protein each provides about 17 kilojoules (approximately 4 kilocalories), while fat provides about 37 kilojoules (approximately 9 kilocalories) (Carreiro 2016). Carbohydrates are primarily contained in grains, cereals and sugar, and in the digestive tract are broken down into glucose. Carbohydrates are the largest nutrient class, and traditionally, the greatest energy source. If energy intake exceeds energy requirements, excess carbohydrates will be mainly stored in the liver as glycogen for later use or be converted to fatty acids when glycogen stores are saturated. In contrast, if the diet contains limited amounts of carbohydrate, the liver converts fat into fatty acids and ketones to replace glucose as an energy source (Paoli 2013). INTRO: Lowâcarbohydrate diets are a broad category of weightâreducing diets and programmes that manipulate and restrict macronutrient (carbohydrate, protein, fat) intake (Astrup 2004;Â Bazzano 2012;Â Campbell 2012;Â Hession 2009). There are no consistent and widely accepted definitions of these diets and different descriptions are used, such as 'lowâcarbohydrate, highâprotein' or 'lowâcarbohydrate, highâfat', depending on the macronutrient manipulation and focus. In practice, lowâcarbohydrate diets are applied in different ways, but generally restrict grains, cereals and legumes, and other foods that contain carbohydrates, such as dairy, most fruit and certain vegetables. The energy required is then typically replaced with food higher in fat and protein, such as meats, eggs, cheese, butter, cream and oils â many of which are animal source foods. Some lowâcarbohydrate diets recommend eating as desired, while others apply restrictions to total energy intake (Atkins 2011;Â Campbell 2012). INTRO: Conventional authorities such as the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA 2017), American Institute of Medicine Food and Nutrition Board (IOM 2005), Australian National Health and Medical Research Council together with the New Zealand Ministry of Health (NHMRC 2006), and the Nordic Council of Ministers, Nordic Committee of Senior Officials for Food Issues (NNR 2012), as well as the UK's Scientific Advisory Committee on Nutrition (SACN 2015), have recommended 45% to 65% of total energy as the appropriate carbohydrate intake for adults. Thus, some people regard lowâcarbohydrate diets to be those with carbohydrate intakes below 45% of total energy. Some published definitions of lowâcarbohydrate diets disregard the official recommendations, and use an upper limit of 40% of total energy from carbohydrates as indicative of a lowâcarbohydrate diet (Frigolet 2011;Â WylieâRosett 2013). In absolute, rather than proportional terms, lowâcarbohydrate diets have been defined as having less than 200 g of carbohydrate (Frigolet 2011), while some disagree with this liberal definition, preferring to distinguish between 'nonâketogenic lowâcarbohydrate diets' as containing 50 g to 150 g of carbohydrates, and 'ketogenic lowâcarbohydrate diets' (or very lowâcarbohydrate diets) as having a maximum of 50 g of carbohydrates, with this latter variant seen by some as being more effective for weight loss (Westman 2007;Â Yancy 2004). Ketogenic diets are characterised by a high production of ketones in the liver as an alternative energy source, as well as high levels of ketones in the blood (ketonaemia) and urine (ketonuria) when fat or protein intake is very high and carbohydrate intake is very low (less than 50 g/day) (Paoli 2013). INTRO: Weightâreducing diets aligned with current dietary recommendations are often referred to as 'lowâfat diets' or 'balanced, weightâreducing diets', and will be referred to as 'balanced diets' in this review (British Dietetic Association 2013). Globally, current dietary recommendations â in terms of macronutrients, micronutrients, food choices and dietary patterns â are generally consistent, and governmental bodies from Europe, the USA, Australia and Nordic countries recommend that 45% to 65% of total energy intake should be provided by carbohydrates, between 10% and 35% by protein and between 20% and 35% by fat (EFSA 2017;Â IOM 2005;Â NHMRC 2006;Â NNR 2012). There is room for flexibility within these ranges from lower to higher intakes of carbohydrate, fat and protein. These dietary recommendations are accompanied by information on 'better food' choices; improving the quality of carbohydrates (e.g. whole grains versus refined grains), protein (e.g. fish versus processed meat) and fat (e.g. olive oil versus butter); as well as on maintaining a healthy body weight by aiming to keep energy intake and energy expenditure balanced. INTRO: Nutrition recommendations are moving away from macronutrientâfocused, single food and single nutrient messages towards recommendations about dietary patterns and âtotal dietsâ (NICE 2014;Â NNR 2012;Â USDA 2014). This has been driven mainly by the lack of clear and consistent associations between individual nutrients (micronutrients and macronutrients) and disease risk, limitations of single nutrient trials, and greater successes of 'total diet' or dietary pattern interventions. INTRO: Dietary patterns can be defined as "the quantities, proportions, variety, or combination of different foods, drinks, and nutrients (when available) in diets, and the frequency with which they are habitually consumed" (USDA 2014). Current evidence supports associations between some dietary patterns and lower risk of obesity and chronic diseases, especially T2DM, cardiovascular disease, hypertension, and certain cancers (DGAC 2015;Â USDA 2014). For example, systematic reviews of large longâterm studies show that several dietary patterns are consistently and equally associated with a lower risk of developing T2DMÂ in the future (Alhazmi 2014;Â Esposito 2014;Â Koloverou 2014). These dietary patterns have different macronutrient compositions, but share several common components, including fruit, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, nuts, healthy oils, adequate proteins (such as seafood and lean meat), reduced intake of red and processed meats and sugarâsweetened beverages, and little or moderate alcohol (Ndanuko 2016;Â NNR 2012;Â USDA 2014). It has been suggested that carbohydrate avoidance and the resultant food restrictions typical of lowâcarbohydrate diets make it difficult to achieve a dietary pattern that is nutrientâ and fibreârich, diverse, and that promotes good health (USDA 2014). INTRO: How the intervention might work INTRO: Energy balance and bodyâweight regulation is complex and interactive, and questions on certain components of energy balance and their interactions â especially over the longer term â are yet to be answered (Hall 2012). The first law of thermodynamics and evidence from various types of studies over the past 50 years, including randomised controlled trials (RCTs), support the view that weight loss occurs when the amount of kilojoules consumed during eating and drinking is less than the amount of kilojoules expended over weeks or months (ACC/AHA 2013 Full Report;Â Hall 2011;Â Hall 2012;Â Hall 2015;Â Jensen 2014). Thus, a plausible mechanism whereby lowâcarbohydrate diets enable weight loss is by achieving a sustained energy deficit over time even when advice to explicitly restrict energy intake is not provided. When people eliminate and restrict carbohydrateârich foods, they are more likely to reduce energy intake because they eat less food (Brehm 2003;Â Sondike 2003). Related mechanisms reported in the literature include a reduction in appetite with lowâcarbohydrate diets, possibly related to the increased intake of fat and production of ketones (Boden 2005;Â Nordmann 2006;Â Westman 2007). Since total energy intake is known to drive changes in body weight, its role must be considered when examining the effect on any diet on weight changes. INTRO: Some literature indicates that certain macronutrients may have metabolic advantages over others, more specifically that lower carbohydrate intake is more effective for weight loss, independent of energy intake (Atkins 2011;Â Westman 2007). However, it has been proposed that when proportions of macronutrients in the diet are changed, rapid physiological adaptations occur that aim to match metabolic fuel selection to the diet. Changes in body composition and energy expenditure may be minimised by these adaptations. In this scenario, in the shorter term, all reduced energy diets would have a similar effect on loss of body fat (Hall 2011;Â Noakes 2006;Â Tay 2008). INTRO: Literature on lowâcarbohydrate diets also suggest that the reduced insulin secretion resulting from a lowâcarbohydrate diet causes greater release of adipose tissue free fatty acids, fat oxidation and energy expenditure, and increased loss of body fat compared to restricting fat intake (Ludwig 2014;Â Taubes 2007;Â Westman 2007). However, a study in 19 obese adults confined to a metabolic ward demonstrated that an equal kilojouleâselective reduction in dietary fat resulted in no changes in insulin secretion, fat oxidation or energy expenditure and a greater net fat loss when compared to restricting carbohydrates by the same amount, which resulted in decreased insulin secretion, increased fat oxidation and decreased energy expenditure (Hall 2015). INTRO: According to recent clinical guidelines for obesity, a highâquality systematic review, a scientific report to inform dietary guidelines and a recent sixâmonth randomised controlled feeding trial, a number of different diets may lead to weight loss over the short term if they achieve a sustained energy deficit, but some of these diets may be more advantageous than others for maintaining longerâterm cardiovascular and metabolic health (DGAC 2015;Â Jensen 2014;Â Johnston 2014;Â Wan 2017). There is evidence that weight loss of 5% and more, or BMI reduction of at least 5%, may result in clinically meaningful improvements in cardio metabolic health following dietary regimens (Brown 2016;Â Truby 2006;Â Wald 2012;Â Wing 2010). INTRO: Adherence and weight maintenance INTRO: Poor dietary adherence has been regarded as one of the reasons popular and traditional dieting strategies are unsuccessful, and it is well known that adherence to nutrition counselling by study participants varies widely. Evidence from quality RCTs, systematic reviews and other study designs suggest that adherence to diets is a primary driver of weightâloss success, regardless of the macronutrient composition, and may explain a considerable part of whether dieters are able to achieve energy deficit for weight loss (Alhassan 2008;Â Dansinger 2005;Â Hall 2011;Â Johnston 2014;Â Sacks 2009). Dietary intake is difficult to measure accurately, and fidelity of application of dietary assessment methods varies widely across studies (Shim 2014), which may introduce a lot of variation into the assessment of adherence. Consequently, data on adherence to assigned diets are often lacking in weightâloss trials. Also, keeping the weight off once lost is also a considerable challenge in treating obesity, with most people tending to relapse (Dietz 2015). Indeed, a systematic review including 56 RCTs reported that dieting to lose weight is most often over weeks, months or years, and it is challenging for most people to maintain the weight lost over the long term (Collins 2013). Thus, ease of adherence to weightâreducing diets is a key factor to consider. It is also necessary to consider the timeâdependant nature of the relationship between diet and weight change when examining the effect of diets on weight change. Trials typically have different periods of followâup, and different frequencies or intervals of study contacts and measurement.Â Tay 2015Â indicated that changes sustained over a 12âmonth period reflects durability of effects over the long term. INTRO: Why it is important to do this review INTRO: The public spends considerable amounts of money and time on trying to diet, on books about diet, and on products and foods to enhance weight loss. It is therefore important to examine scientific evidence behind the claims made. INTRO: Some advocates claim lowâcarbohydrate diets decrease cardiovascular disease and diabetes risk profiles: reducing triglycerides, increasing highâdensity lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol and improving glycaemic control over one year (Stern 2004); improving triglycerides, HDL cholesterol and glycaemic control over four years (Wing 2010); and improving aortic stiffness over four weeks (SyedâAbdul 2018). However, the diets are not without potential side effects. These include gastrointestinal disturbances, such as constipation, flatulence, indigestion or diarrhoea over the short term (Bhardwaj 2017;Â Brinkworth 2009a;Â Saslow 2014); and increasing lowâdensity lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol and nonâHDL cholesterol over 12 months (Brinkworth 2009b;Â Wan 2017). Some participants report mood disturbance and impaired ability to concentrate (Brinkworth 2009c;Â Halyburton 2007). Other side effects of lowâcarbohydrate diets include lack of appetite, bad breath, headaches, muscle cramps, general weakness and hair loss (Foster 2010;Â Rio 2001;Â Yancy 2004). INTRO: A prospective cohort study and metaâanalysis that combined 25âyear followâup of the Atherosclerosis Risk in Community (ARIC) data (USA) and seven other cohort studies (USA, Europe, Asia and multinational) assessed the association between carbohydrate intake and mortality (Seidelmann 2018). Findings indicated that both highâ and lowâcarbohydrate diets increased mortality, with the lowest risk observed among those who consumed a diet containing 50% to 55% carbohydrates. The lowâcarbohydrate dietary patterns that favoured animal fat and protein sources were associated with higher mortality, while those that favoured plantâbased foods were associated with lower mortality. Additionally, diets very high in animal source foods could pose a significant threat to environmental sustainability (Sabate 2014;Â Soret 2014). INTRO: The debate on effective and safe diets for treating obesity continues. Many trials and systematic reviews involving obese people (with and without comorbidities), of varying methodological quality, have assessed the effects of lowâcarbohydrate diets on weight and other risk factors. Â A number of these studies show little or no clinically important difference in weight loss of up to two years' followâup (Chawla 2020;Â Dong 2020;Â Van Zuuren 2018). A systematic review of eight RCTs found that improvements in psychosocial outcomes occur in participants on shortâ and longerâterm weightâloss programmes, regardless of the macronutrient composition of the diet (Ghoch 2016). However, lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets continue to be widely promoted, marketed and commercialised as being more effective for weight loss, and healthier, than weightâreducing diets that have 'balanced' or macronutrient compositions in line with current global dietary recommendations. Healthcare officials argue that very restrictive carbohydrate diets do not promote behaviour changes that foster varied, nutrientâ and fibreârich dietary patterns (USDA 2014), known to reduce risks of cardiovascular disease, hypertension, T2DMÂ and certain cancers. Extreme restriction or excess of macronutrients, as advised with very lowâcarbohydrate diets, instead promote a way of eating that is likely to result in an imbalance of macronutrient intake, suboptimal micronutrient intake and increased disease risk over time. INTRO: Previously, we took stock of existing systematic reviews on lowâcarbohydrate diets for adults wanting to lose weight. We found 50 existing reviews (last search date: 3 March 2014), with a number of shortcomings as reported inÂ Naude 2014. This exercise helped inform the protocol for our earlier systematic review and metaâanalysis of RCTs (Naude 2014). This Cochrane Review will be a fresh edition toÂ Naude 2014, by taking into account new eligible trials, and comments and criticisms generated by the earlier work. INTRO: Objectives INTRO: To compare the effects of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets to weightâreducing diets with balanced ranges of carbohydrates, in relation to changes in weight and cardiovascular risk, in overweight and obese adults without T2DMÂ (comparisons 1 and 2) and with T2DMÂ (comparisons 3 and 4) METHODS: Methods METHODS: Criteria for considering studies for this review METHODS: Types of studies METHODS: As per our protocol (Naude 2019), we included parallelâarm individualâ and clusterârandomised controlled trials (RCTs) that had an active weightâreducing intervention phase of at least 12 weeks. According toÂ Jensen 2014, obese individuals on a moderately restricted energy intake can potentially lose between six and eight kilograms, or five to ten per cent of initial body weight (clinically meaningful) over a sixâmonth period. From this, we inferred that it would be plausible to lose five per cent of initial weight over a threeâmonth period. According to the UK National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE), 12 weeks is the standard length for most commissioned dietary interventions (Ahern 2017;Â NICE 2014). Followâup of participants after the intervention ended could be of any duration. METHODS: We excluded quasiârandomised trials (that is, trials that used an inadequate method of randomisation, such as alternation or date of birth). We included crossâover trials where the first phase was 12 weeks or longer, and where data for the first phase per group were available. We excluded crossâover trials not meeting these criteria due to the possible period and carryâover effects that would arise with the eligible dietary interventions, condition (overweight and obesity) and outcomes in this review, with these not being easily reversible as required for a valid crossâover design (Younge 2015). METHODS: We only included studies with a weightâmaintenance phase if the preceding weightâreducing phase was for 12 weeks or longer, and relevant data from this phase were available. We separated analyses for weightâreducing and weightâmaintenance phases. METHODS: Types of participants METHODS: We included adults (18 years and older) who were overweight or living with obesity (as defined by trial authors), with or without T2DM, and with or without cardiovascular conditions or risk factors such as hypertension or dyslipidaemia (as defined by trial authors). METHODS: We excluded studies where pregnant and lactating women were included, as well as studies in people with specific medical conditions such as bipolar disorder, polycystic ovary syndrome, chronic renal disease, and so on. METHODS: We included studies involving a subset of eligible participants (for example, adults and children, as defined by trial authors) if results were reported separately for the eligible subset (for example, those â¥ 18 years). If not, we only included such studies if 80% or more of the baseline sample were eligible for our review (for example, aged â¥ 18 years). We excluded data from such studies in sensitivity analyses to test the robustness of the primary metaâanalyses. METHODS: Types of interventions METHODS: Treatment diet METHODS: We included RCTs investigating lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets where the diets were explicitly implemented for the primary purpose of reducing weight, with or without explicit advice to restrict total energy intake. METHODS: Control diet METHODS: We included RCTs where the control diets had a carbohydrate content within the balanced range of 45% to 65% of total energy, and where the diets were explicitly implemented for the primary purpose of reducing weight, with or without advice to restrict total energy intake. METHODS: We included studies where diets were implemented by provision of advice, food or both. However, we excluded studies with the following. METHODS: Treatment diet had carbohydrate content 45% or more of total energy or more than 150 g per day. METHODS: Treatment and control diets were different in some other respect that may influence the predefined outcomes, except for total energy intake. METHODS: Treatment or control diets were not adequately defined (and could not be obtained from study authors) or where the control diet was âno dietary intervention'. METHODS: Diets were combined with any other coâinterventions (e.g. exercise, pharmacological, surgical) where these differed by group. METHODS: Dietary interventions had an exclusive focus on energy restriction (i.e. no macronutrient manipulation was explicitly instituted). METHODS: Interventions focused solely on specific foods (e.g. oats), food groups (e.g. dairy) or food components (e.g. plant sterols), or where meal replacements or supplements were part of the diets and were different in the diets being compared. METHODS: Participants were selected based on a possible prognostic variable (for example, genotype). METHODS: Types of outcome measures METHODS: We did not exclude studies on the basis of outcomes measured. However, we did exclude studies measuring only immediate meal responses (e.g. postprandial changes in blood sugar) and not longerâterm physiological responses to diet. METHODS: Primary outcomes METHODS: Change in body weight (kg) from baseline METHODS: Number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% from baseline METHODS: We assessed the primary outcomes at shortâterm (3 months to < 12 months) and longâterm (â¥ 12 months) followâup. METHODS: Secondary outcomes METHODS: Clinical METHODS: Change in body mass index (BMI; kg/m2) from baseline METHODS: Number of participants per group with reduction in BMI of at least 5% from baseline METHODS: We assessed the above clinical outcomes at shortâterm (three months to < 12 months) and longâterm (â¥ 12 months) followâup. METHODS: Change in diastolic blood pressure (mmHg) METHODS: Change in systolic blood pressure (mmHg) METHODS: Allâcause mortality METHODS: Cardiovascular mortality METHODS: Nonâfatal myocardial infarction METHODS: Nonâfatal stroke METHODS: Diagnosis of T2DMÂ (as reported by study authors) METHODS: We assessed these clinical outcomes at longâterm (â¥ 12 months) followâup only. METHODS: Laboratory METHODS: Change in glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c) (%) METHODS: Change in serum lowâdensity lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol (mmol/L) METHODS: Change in serum highâdensity lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol (mmol/L) METHODS: Change in serum nonâHDL cholesterol (mmol/L) METHODS: Change in serum total cholesterol (mmol/L) METHODS: Change in serum triglycerides (mmol/L) METHODS: We assessed these laboratory outcomes at longâterm (â¥ 12 months) followâup only. METHODS: Participantâreported adverse effects METHODS: Participantâreported adverse effects, specifically in regard to lack of appetite, bad breath, weakness, headaches, gastrointestinal problems (constipation, diarrhoea, flatulence, indigestion) and psychosocial problems (mood disturbances) at any time point, limited to those described in included studies. We regarded constipation as a patientâimportant outcome since it is frequently reported by people following lowâcarbohydrate diets. METHODS: Search methods for identification of studies METHODS: We used a comprehensive search strategy aiming to identify all eligible studies regardless of language or publication status. METHODS: Electronic searches METHODS: We identified RCTs through systematic searches of the following bibliographic databases: METHODS: MEDLINE (PubMed, from 1946 to 25 June 2021) METHODS: Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL; 2021, Issue 6), in the Cochrane Library METHODS: Embase (Ovid, from 1947 to 28 June 2021) METHODS: Web of Science Core Collection with Indexes SCIâExpanded, SSCi, CPCIâS (Clarivate Analytics, from 1970 to 25 June 2021) METHODS: We also on 25 June 2021 searched ClinicalTrials.gov () and the WHO International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (ICTRP)Â for ongoing and unpublished trials (). METHODS: We first designed the search strategy for MEDLINE (PubMed) and then adapted it for use in the other sources (Appendix 1).Â METHODS: We did not do a separate search for adverse effects of interventions; we only considered adverse effects reported in included studies. METHODS: Searching other resources METHODS: We checked reference lists of all included studies and relevant systematic reviews identified for additional references to trials. We set out to examine any relevant retraction statements and errata for included studies; however, we did not come across any. METHODS: Data collection and analysis METHODS: Selection of studies METHODS: Â We imported all deâduplicated search records intoÂ Covidence. Two review authors independently screened the titles and abstracts of these records to identify all potential eligible studies. Discrepancies in firstâline screening choices were resolved by discussion among at least two review authors. We retrieved the fullâtext report for each record that the screeners considered potentially eligible, and two review authors (CN, KN, AS, AB) independently screened all full texts, identifying studies for inclusion, and identifying and recording reasons for exclusion of the ineligible studies. We resolved any disagreement through discussion or, if required, consultation with a third review author (TY, JV). We identified and excluded duplicates and collated multiple reports of the same study so that each study, rather than each report, was the unit of interest in the review. We recorded the selection process in sufficient detail to complete a PRISMA flow diagram (Moher 2009), and 'Characteristics of excluded studies' table. Studies where full reports (published or unpublished) were not available (e.g. conference abstracts), or where there was unclear or missing information (that could not be obtained from study authors) such that we could not ascertain study eligibility, were placed, with a reason, in the 'Characteristics of studies awaiting classification' table. METHODS: Data extraction and management METHODS: To extract study characteristics and outcome data, we created a data collection form in DistillerSR (DistillerSR), and piloted it on two included studies. Data from each included study were extracted independently by two review authors (AB, KN, AS, CN). We contacted the study authors when reported information was unclear or contradictory, or when important data were missing. It was not necessary to seek translations. We extracted the following: METHODS: Methods: authors' contact details, type of record (e.g. journal article, thesis), study design, study population, study dates, total duration of the intervention and followâup duration after the intervention where relevant, details of 'runâin' periods where relevant, number of study centres and location, study setting, method of recruitment, number of study arms, description of eligible study arms, outcome used for sample size calculation, unit of allocation, number randomised per study arm (for individuallyârandomised trials), number of clusters and number of participants per cluster who consented (for clusterârandomised trials), number of withdrawals and those lost to followâup, number completed and analysed, other relevant notes on the methods. METHODS: Participants: inclusion and exclusion criteria, age, gender (number of male and female participants per group), baseline body weight status, other baseline cardiovascular disease risk factors and potential confounders, any group differences. METHODS: Interventions: treatment diet, control diet, implementation or delivery of diets, dietary intake assessments (e.g. what, how frequent, by whom), concomitant interventions. METHODS: Outcomes: primary and secondary outcomes specified and collected at relevant time points, data on adherence to the interventions, and whether primary study authors analysed results separately according to gender. METHODS: Notes: study funding, conflicts of interest declarations of study authors, and other relevant notes. METHODS: For outcomes, we extracted change data (i.e. change from baseline to outcome assessment per group) where possible, with relevant data on variance for treatment and control arms and numbers of participants per arm at that time point. Where change data were not available, we extracted and used data at study end (i.e. end values), or other relevant time points, along with variance and number of participants per arm at that time point.Â METHODS: Where possible, we converted variables to comparable units to allow pooling of data, if appropriate.Â CallejaâFernÃ¡ndez 2012Â stratified by homeostatic model assessment (insulin resistant (IR) and insulin sensitive (IS)) before randomisation. We combined IR and IS group data using Cochrane methods to combine subgroups (Higgins 2021).Â Saslow 2017aÂ reported appetite change as hunger change scores using means and Cohen's d values for each diet group. We converted Cohen's d values to standard deviations (SD) using the formula SD = mean/Cohen's d.Â METHODS: We stratified included trials into those in participants without T2DM (comparisons 1 and 2)Â and those in participants with T2DM (comparisons 3 and 4).Â Â METHODS: We resolved disagreements by consensus or by involving a third review author (MC, TY, JV). We exported data from DistillerSR and imported it into the latest version of Review Manager Web (RevMan Web 2020) via Microsoft Excel. We completed the 'Characteristics of included studies' table for all included studies. We used key items from the TIDieR checklist (Hoffman 2014) to aid description, interpretation and discussion of the results. Brief details of ongoing studies are reported in the 'Characteristics of ongoing studies' table, and these studies will be considered for inclusion in a future update of the review. METHODS: Assessment of risk of bias in included studies METHODS: Three reviewers (CN, AB and AS) assessed risk of bias for each study using the Cochrane Risk of Bias 2 tool (RoB2) for randomised controlled trials (Sterne 2019). This tool was used to assess the effect of the assignment to the intervention, for the following domains: METHODS: bias arising from the randomisation process; METHODS: bias due to deviations from intended interventions; METHODS: bias due to missing outcome data; METHODS: bias in measurement of the outcome; METHODS: bias in selection of the reported result. METHODS: We did not have to carry out the planned assessments of risk of bias for crossâover and clusterârandomised controlled trials, as none of the eligible trials had these designs.Â METHODS: We judged each domain as either 'low risk of bias', 'some concerns' or 'high risk of bias' for the following outcomes reported in the summary of findings tables: METHODS: change in body weight (kg) measured from baseline to between three and < 12 months; METHODS: change in body weight (kg) measured from baseline to â¥ 12 months; METHODS: number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% measured from baseline to â¥ 12 months; METHODS: cardiovascular mortality measured from baseline to â¥ 12 months; METHODS: change in diastolic blood pressure (mmHg) measured from baseline to â¥ 12 months; METHODS: change in HbA1c (%) (forÂ comparisons in participants with T2DM) measured from baseline to â¥ 12 months; METHODS: change in serum LDL cholesterol (mmol/L) measured from baseline to â¥ 12 months; METHODS: participantâreported constipation at any time point from baseline to three and < 12 months. METHODS: Overall, per included study, we made judgements according to the following criteria: METHODS: low risk of bias: when all domains were at low risk; METHODS: some concerns: when one or more domains had some concerns, but none were at a high risk of bias; METHODS: high risk of bias: when one or more domains were at high risk of bias, or multiple domains had some concerns to the extent that these reduced confidence in the results. METHODS: We resolved any disagreements by discussion or by involving another review author(MC or AS). METHODS: Measures of treatment effect METHODS: For dichotomous data, we used the number of events as the numerator and the total sample size per outcome as the denominator in each relevant comparison group and computed the risk ratio (RR) (available case data). For continuous data, we reported results per outcome as the difference in the mean change (and, if not available, the difference in end values) between the treatment and control groups, and computed the mean difference (MD) (available case data). We entered data presented as a scale with a consistent direction of effect. We used Review Manager Web to conduct metaâanalyses for each outcome, where appropriate, to determine a pooled effect of lowâcarbohydrate diets compared to balancedâcarbohydrate diets. We narratively described skewed data reported as medians and interquartile ranges. METHODS: Unit of analysis issues METHODS: In the case of multiple intervention groups, we selected one pair of interventions (treatment and control) most relevant to this systematic review question. We did not need to apply the planned approach for unit of analysis issues related to clustering as no clusterârandomised trials were eligible. Where a study reported outcome data for more than one time point within our time point categories (3 months to < 12 months; and â¥ 12 months), we used the longest time point (for example, where results were available at three months and five months, we only used the fiveâmonth data). METHODS: Dealing with missing data METHODS: We contacted study authors or sponsors to clarify key study characteristics and obtain missing numerical outcome data, where needed. Where study authors had not reported all relevant statistics per outcome (for example, sample size, mean change and standard deviation of change per group), we calculated or estimated the required data from other reported statistics using formulas specified in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Higgins 2011), if possible. Where we could not calculate or estimate these statistics with reasonable confidence, we contacted the study authors by email. When we did not receive a response, we did not impute the missing values, but reported the available results narratively or in a table, as appropriate. For interventions in which there was substantial attrition (15% or more for at least one of the groups) of study participants, we reported the attrition rate. We also performed sensitivity analyses excluding studies with some concerns or a high risk of bias for the missing outcome data domain in RoB 2. METHODS: Assessment of heterogeneity METHODS: We examined heterogeneity per outcome firstly by visual inspection of the forest plots (i.e. we looked at physical overlap of confidence intervals across the included studies). Secondly, we assessed statistical heterogeneity among the intervention effects across the included studies in each metaâanalysis as follows: METHODS: Chi2 test for heterogeneity METHODS: I2 statistic to quantify heterogeneity METHODS: Tau2 statistic to measure the extent of heterogeneity METHODS: In our metaâanalyses, we considered substantial heterogeneity as an I2 statistic value of greater than 50% and either a Chi2 test of less than 0.1 or Tau2 statistic greater than 0. In metaâanalyses with substantial heterogeneity, we performed prespecified subgroup analyses on the outcomes in the summary of findings tables. Where we identified unexplained substantial heterogeneity, we did not pool results into an overall effect estimate but rather presented the individual effect sizes per study for the specific outcome.Â METHODS: Assessment of reporting biases METHODS: Where data per comparison and outcome allowed us to pool more than 10 studies, we explored the possibility of small study biases for the primary outcomes using funnel plots. In the case of asymmetry, we considered various explanations such as publication bias, poor study design and the effect of study size. METHODS: Data synthesis METHODS: We used a randomâeffects model for metaâanalyses since we anticipated heterogeneity between included studies due to variations in the composition of weightâloss diets, adherence to diets, intervention duration and dietary assessment methodology. For dichotomous outcomes, we used the MantelâHaenszel method, unless the number of events were not available but estimates of effect measure and their standard errors were, in which case we used the inverse variance method. For continuous outcomes, we used the inverse variance method. METHODS: We analysed trials in overweight and obese participants without T2DMÂ following diets with a weightâreducing phase only (comparison 1), or a weightâreducing phase followed by a weightâmaintenance phase (comparison 2); as well as overweight and obese participants with T2DMÂ following diets with a weightâreducing phase only (comparison 3), or a weightâreducing phase followed by a weightâmaintenance phase (comparison 4). These analyses were done separately, where possible, as the presence of diabetes is likely to influence the effects of the diets. When not explicitly stated, we regarded weightâmaintenance phases as periods where initial diet prescriptions or advice changed to indicate less focus on active weight reduction, for example, changes in energy prescriptions or no restrictions on carbohydrate intake.Â METHODS: We analysed outcome data at the time point â¥ 12 months, because it captures sustainability of effects on weight loss, clinical, as well as laboratory outcomes. However, for the weight and BMI outcomes, we also analysed data at the time point three months to < 12 months, as many people going on weightâloss diets are especially interested to know how fast they would be losing weight, and experienced weight loss over the short term also serves as motivation to keep going longer term. METHODS: We preferentially extracted and used data from the intentionâtoâtreat (ITT) analyses of trials (as reported by trial authors) in all our metaâanalyses. By ITT, we mean that randomised participants were analysed according to the group to which they were randomised; however, if there were missing data we did not perform any imputations. METHODS: Subgroup analysis and investigation of heterogeneity METHODS: Where data allowed, we carried out the following subgroup analyses for the outcomes in the summary of findings tables, to explore substantial heterogeneity and the stability of findings in different study subgroups, as follows. METHODS: By extent of carbohydrate restriction (i.e. very lowâcarbohydrate or ketogenic diets: carbohydrate prescription of â¤ 50 g per day or < 10% of total daily energy intake from a nominal 8400 kilojoule (approximately 2000 kilocalories) diet; and nonâketogenic lowâcarbohydrate diets: > 50 g to 150 g per day or < 45% of total energy intake) METHODS: By similarity of total energy prescription (i.e. studies with substantial differences in daily total energy prescription (> 500 kilojoules or approximately 120 kilocalories) in treatment and control groups, for example, ad libitum energy prescription in the treatment diet and restricted energy prescription in the control diet, studies with similar energy prescription or similar approach used to restrict energy intake in treatment and control groups, studies with no energy prescription reported or unrestricted energy intake prescribed in both treatment and control groups) METHODS: By diagnosed cardiovascular event or disease (i.e. studies in people with no events or disease, studies in people with events or disease, and studies in people with and without events or disease) METHODS: By gender METHODS: Sensitivity analysis METHODS: Where data allowed, we carried out sensitivity analyses for primary outcomes, assessing the effect of: METHODS: overall low risk and 'some concerns' of bias (i.e. we first pooled all relevant studies per outcome, and then pooled only studies with overall low risk and 'some concerns' of bias); METHODS: attrition bias (i.e. we first pooled all relevant studies per outcome, and then pooled only studies at low risk of bias for the missing outcome data domain); METHODS: studies including only a subset of eligible participants for this review (i.e. we first pooled all relevant studies per outcome, and then pooled only studies that included only participants eligible for inclusion in this review);Â METHODS: clustering (i.e. we first pooled all relevant studies per outcome, and then pooled only studies that randomised individual participants); and METHODS: source of funding (i.e. we first pooled studies with all funding sources, and then pooled only studies without diet/food industry funding). METHODS: Summary of findings and assessment of the certainty of the evidence METHODS: Based on the methods described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions (Higgins 2011), we prepared four summary of findings tables, one for each comparison in participants without and with T2DM. In these tables, we included change in body weight (kg) measured from baseline to between three and < 12 months, and the following outcomes measured from baseline to â¥ 12 months: change in body weight (kg); number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5%; cardiovascular mortality; change in diastolic blood pressure (mmHg); change in HbA1c (%) (for comparisons 3 and 4 in participants with T2DM); change in serum LDL cholesterol (mmol/L), as well as participantâreported constipation at 3 to < 12 months. We used the GRADE approach to rank the certainty of the evidence as it related to the studies that contributed data to the metaâanalyses for the prespecified outcomes, using GRADEpro GDT software (). The GRADE tool includes five considerations (study limitations, inconsistencies of results, imprecision, indirectness and publication bias) to assess the certainty of the evidence from RCTs. METHODS: We justified all decisions to downgrade the quality of evidence using footnotes, and made comments to aid readers' understanding where necessary. METHODS: Three review authors (CN, AS, AB) made judgements about evidence certainty, with disagreements resolved by discussion, and involving a third review author where needed. METHODS: We extracted study data, formatted our comparisons in data tables and prepared a summary of findings table for each of the four comparisonsÂ before writing the results and conclusions of our review. RESULTS: Results RESULTS: Description of studies RESULTS: See: Characteristics of included studies; Characteristics of excluded studies; Characteristics of ongoing studies; Characteristics of studies awaiting classification. RESULTS: Results of the search RESULTS: Our electronic and manual searches yielded 5563 references, which includedÂ screening the reference lists of included trials and existing systematic reviews, with 2882 remaining after duplicate removal. We screened the titles and abstracts of these records and identified 475 as potentially eligibleÂ and obtained their full texts. We included 61 trials from 113Â references (Figure 1), of which three did not provide data that could be used in the quantitative syntheses (metaâanalyses) (Foster 2003;Â Pittas 2005;Â Racette 1995). RESULTS: Included studies RESULTS: Study locations and participants RESULTS: We included 61 parallelâarm individualÂ RCTs that randomised 6925 participants to either lowâcarbohydrate or balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets, and were published between 1978 and 2021. All trialsÂ were done in highâincome countries, except for one in China (Liu 2013); with 26 in the USA (Aude 2004;Â Bales 2017;Â Bazzano 2014;Â Brehm 2003;Â BrehmÂ 2005;Â Cornier 2005;Â Ebbeling 2007;Evangelista 2021Â Foraker 2014;Â Foster 2003;Â Foster 2010;Â Gardner 2007;Â Kitabchi 2013;Â Landers 2002;Â Lasker 2008;Â Layman 2005;Â Layman 2009;Â Pittas 2005;Â Racette 1995;Â Ruth 2013;Â Sacks 2009;Â Samaha 2003;Â Saslow 2017a;Â Stentz 2016;Â Volek 2009;Â Westman 2008); 14 in Australia (BenassiâEvans 2009;Â Farnsworth 2003;Â Griffin 2013;Â Jesudason 2013;Â Keogh 2007;Â Larsen 2011;Â Lim 2010;Â Parr 2016;Â Pedersen 2014;Â Tay 2008;Â Tay 2014;Â Watson 2016;Â Wycherley 2010;Â Wycherley 2012); five in Spain (CallejaâFernÃ¡ndez 2012;Â Goni 2018;Â JuanolaâFalgarona 2014;Â MarcoâBenedi 2019;Â MateoâGallego 2017); three in the UK (Dyson 2007;Â Hockaday 1978;Â Lean 1997), two in Sweden (Guldbrand 2012;Â Mellberg 2014), Norway (Klemsdal 2010;Â Veum 2017), Germany (Frisch 2009;Â Haufe 2013) andÂ Japan (Sato 2017;Â Yamada 2014);Â and one each in Canada (Josse 2011), Israel (Elhayany 2010), Singapore (Ooi 2021) and New Zealand (Krebs 2012). The large majority of trials were undertaken in outpatient clinics, medical centres andÂ research centres (50/61 trials), with the remaining 11 not reporting aÂ specific study setting. See theÂ Characteristics of included studiesÂ for additional details per study.Â RESULTS: Type 2 diabetes mellitus status of participants RESULTS: We stratified trials into those in participants without T2DM (comparisons 1 and 2)Â and those in participants with T2DM (comparisons 3 and 4), and also separated findings where people implemented only an active weightâreducing phase of the diets, from findings where people implemented a weightâreducing phase followed by a weightâmaintenance phase of the diets, as follows:Â RESULTS: comparison 1: trials in participants without T2DM including only weightâreducing phases of diets; RESULTS: comparison 2: trials in participants without T2DM including weightâreducing phases of diets followed by weightâmaintenance phases; RESULTS: comparison 3: trials in participants with T2DM including only weightâreducing phases of diets; RESULTS: comparison 4: trials in participants with T2DM including weightâreducing phases of diets followed by weightâmaintenance phases. RESULTS: WeÂ included 45/61 trialsÂ (n = 5118 randomised) in the two comparisons in participants without T2DM (comparisons 1 and 2). Of these, 36Â trials explicitly excluded participants with T2DM. For the remaining trials withÂ mixed participantsÂ or where this was unclearÂ (n = 9), the participants'Â baseline characteristicsÂ (e.g. HbA1c, fasting insulin, use of diabetes medication) were not indicative of diabetes (Bales 2017;Â Foraker 2014;Â Liu 2013;Â MarcoâBenedi 2019), more than 90% of the sampleÂ did not haveÂ T2DM (Aude 2004;Â Frisch 2009), participants with unstable metabolic disease were excluded (Jesudason 2013), or no relevant information was reported or could be obtained (Layman 2005;Â Layman 2009). RESULTS: We included 14/61 trialsÂ (n = 1604Â participants randomised) in the two comparisons in participants with T2DM (comparisons 3 and 4). Thirteen of theseÂ trials were conducted in participants withÂ diagnosed T2DM (Elhayany 2010;Â Evangelista 2021;Â Guldbrand 2012;Â Hockaday 1978;Â Krebs 2012;Â Larsen 2011;Â Pedersen 2014;Â Sato 2017;Â Tay 2014;Â Watson 2016;Â Westman 2008;Â Wycherley 2010;Â Yamada 2014). The other trial had mixed participants withÂ eligibility criteria being diabetes or prediabetes and more than 70% of participants were on diabetes medication at baselineÂ (Saslow 2017a). RESULTS: Two trials (n = 158 participants randomised) were conducted in participants without and with T2DMÂ and reported data separately for all (Dyson 2007), or some outcomes (Samaha 2003), which we included in theÂ appropriate comparisons, where possible. For the descriptions of participants, treatment and control diets that follow in this section, these two trialsÂ (Dyson 2007;Â Samaha 2003), are included with both strata of participants (without and with T2DM).Â RESULTS: Participants without T2DM: weightâreducing phase only (comparison 1) and weightâreducing phase followed by a weightâmaintenance phase (comparison 2) RESULTS: Sample size: The total numbers of participants randomised to the treatment and control diet arms ranged widely across these trials. The smallest trial randomised 20 participants (Racette 1995). Other small trials with 40 or fewer participants randomised includedÂ Cornier 2005;Â Dyson 2007;Â Kitabchi 2013Â andÂ Layman 2005. The largest trial in participants without T2DM wasÂ Sacks 2009Â (n = 405 randomised), with other trials including > 150 participants beingÂ Foster 2010;Â Frisch 2009;Â Haufe 2013;Â Jesudason 2013;Â andÂ Klemsdal 2010. RESULTS: Gender and age: In three of these trials, only men were eligibleÂ (BenassiâEvans 2009;Â Veum 2017;Â Wycherley 2012), in 16 only womenÂ (Bales 2017;Â Brehm 2003;Â BrehmÂ 2005;Â Cornier 2005;Â Foraker 2014;Â Gardner 2007;Â Griffin 2013;Â Jesudason 2013;Â Josse 2011;Â Kitabchi 2013;Â Layman 2005;Â Lean 1997;Â Liu 2013;Â MateoâGallego 2017;Â Mellberg 2014;Â Racette 1995),Â and in the rest,Â both men and women were eligible. Mean baseline age of participants across these trials was 45 years (range: 22 to 62Â years). RESULTS: Weight status: At baseline,Â mean body weight and BMI of participants without T2DM was 93.9 kg (range: 65 to 132 kg) and 33.6 kg/m2 (range:Â 30 to 43Â kg/m2), respectively. RESULTS: Cardiovascular health and risk factors: The majority of these trialsÂ included participants without cardiovascular conditions, risk factors or events at baseline (n = 30), one included participants with and without these (Aude 2004), and for theÂ remainingÂ trialsÂ this was unclear (Bales 2017;Â CallejaâFernÃ¡ndez 2012;Â Dyson 2007;Â Foraker 2014;Â JuanolaâFalgarona 2014;Â Keogh 2007;Â Kitabchi 2013;Â Lasker 2008;Â Layman 2005;Â MarcoâBenedi 2019;Â MateoâGallego 2017;Â Samaha 2003;Â Stentz 2016;Â Veum 2017;Â Volek 2009). Mean baseline LDL cholesterol concentration across these trials was 3.28 mmol/L (range: 2.58 to 4.47 mmol/L) and mean baseline DBP was 79 mmHg (range: 62 to 92 mmHg). RESULTS: Participants with T2DM: weightâreducing phase only (comparison 3) and weightâreducing phase followed by a weightâmaintenance phase (comparison 4) RESULTS: Sample size: The smallest trial in participants with T2DM randomised a total of 24 participants to the treatment and control diet arms (Yamada 2014), with other small trials (40 or fewer participants randomised) beingÂ Dyson 2007;Â Saslow 2017a;Â andÂ Wycherley 2010. The largest trial in participants with T2DM randomised 419 participants (Krebs 2012). Other trials including more than 130 participants wereÂ Elhayany 2010;Â Samaha 2003;Â andÂ Tay 2014. RESULTS: Gender and age: In all trials in participants with T2DM, both men and women were eligible for inclusion. Mean age of participants at baseline was 57 years (range: 50Â to 65Â years). RESULTS: Weight status: Mean baseline body weight of participants across these trials was 96.7 kg (range: 67 to 132 kg) and mean BMI was 34.5 kg/m2 (range 25Â to 42.9Â kg/m2). RESULTS: HbA1c: Mean baseline HbA1c of participants across these trials was 7.64% (range: 6.6% to 8.8%). RESULTS: Cardiovascular health: Six of these trials included participantsÂ without cardiovascular conditions, risk factors or events at baseline (Hockaday 1978;Â Krebs 2012;Â Larsen 2011;Â Tay 2014;Â Watson 2016;Â Wycherley 2010), one included participants with heart failure (Evangelista 2021), and, for the rest of the trials, this was unclear. Mean baseline LDL cholesterol across these trials was 2.63 mmol/L (range: 1.7 to 3.2 mmol/L) and mean baseline DBP was 78 mmHg (range: 70 to 84 mmHg). RESULTS: Treatment and control diets RESULTS: Trials in participants without T2DM: weightâreducing phase only (comparison 1) and weightâreducing phase followed by a weightâmaintenance phase (comparison 2) RESULTS: Duration: The duration of the weightâreducing phases of diets tested in these trials ranged from 12 weeks to two years, as follows: 10 trials for 12 weeks (Aude 2004;Â Dyson 2007;Â Farnsworth 2003;Â Keogh 2007;Â Landers 2002;Â Liu 2013;Â Racette 1995;Â Ruth 2013;Â Veum 2017;Â Volek 2009), eight trials for 16 weeks (BrehmÂ 2005;Â Cornier 2005;Â Goni 2018;Â Josse 2011;Â Lasker 2008;Â Layman 2005;Â Ooi 2021;Â Parr 2016), 12 trials for six months (Bales 2017;Â Brehm 2003;Â Foster 2003;Â Foster 2010;Â Haufe 2013;Â JuanolaâFalgarona 2014;Â Kitabchi 2013;Â Lean 1997;Â MarcoâBenedi 2019;Â MateoâGallego 2017;Â Pittas 2005;Â Stentz 2016), 12 trials for one year (Bazzano 2014;Â BenassiâEvans 2009;Â CallejaâFernÃ¡ndez 2012;Â Foraker 2014;Â Frisch 2009;Â Gardner 2007;Â Griffin 2013;Â Klemsdal 2010;Â Layman 2009;Â Samaha 2003;Â Tay 2008;Â Wycherley 2012), one trial for 15 months (Lim 2010), one trial for 18 months (Ebbeling 2007), and three trials for two years (Jesudason 2013;Â Mellberg 2014;Â Sacks 2009). We used only the data from the first six months in two trials with total durations of one year (Foster 2003) and two years (Foster 2010) since the treatment diets were ineligible from six months onwards due to the prescribed incremental carbohydrate increases. The results for only the active weightâreducing phases of the diets in participants without T2DM were reported in comparison 1. RESULTS: Five of these trials also implemented a weightâmaintenance phase following the weightâreducing phase for six weeks (Racette 1995), 40 weeks (Keogh 2007), 56 weeks (Farnsworth 2003), a variable time period with an average of 18 months (Haufe 2013) and 21 months (Dyson 2007), and these results were reported in comparison 2. Implementation ofÂ these incremental increases varied widely across the five trials, with the prescribed time for following the very lowâcarbohydrate diets rangingÂ from one week toÂ three months. Different prescriptions for incremental increasesÂ in carbohydrate intake in the later phases included increases from 10% to 27% of total energy as carbohydrates, by 5 g/day/week,Â by 10 gÂ weekly, andÂ from 20 g to 50 g per day. As expected, the protein and fat proportions of treatment dietsÂ also varied concordantly.Â The control diets in theÂ majority of trials in participants without T2DM were balanced for carbohydrates, fat and protein (n = 38) (Table 6).Â RESULTS: The most common diets comparedÂ across the trials in participants without T2DM wereÂ lowâcarbohydrate, balancedâfat and highâprotein treatment diets compared to control diets balancedÂ for all three macronutrients (n = 19), followed by very lowâcarbohydrate treatment diets with unspecified fat and protein contents compared to control diets with balanced proportions ofÂ carbohydrates, fat and protein (n = 7)Â (Table 6). RESULTS: Total energy prescription: In most of these trials, the total energy prescription was similar, or the approach used to restrict energy intake was similar in treatment and control groups (n = 34). In nine other trials, the energy prescription was ad libitum in the treatment diets and restricted in the control diets (Aude 2004;Â Brehm 2003;Â BrehmÂ 2005;Â Foster 2003;Â Foster 2010;Â Gardner 2007;Â Landers 2002;Â Liu 2013;Â Samaha 2003). In the remaining trials, no energy prescription was reported, or unrestricted energy intake was prescribed for both treatment and control diets (Bazzano 2014;Â Ebbeling 2007;Â Mellberg 2014;Â Volek 2009). RESULTS: Trials in participants with T2DM: weightâreducing phase only (comparison 3) and weightâreducing phase followed by a weightâmaintenance phase (comparison 4) RESULTS: Duration: The duration of the weightâreducing phases of diets tested in these trials ranged from 12 weeks to two years, as follows: four trials for 12 weeks (Dyson 2007;Â Evangelista 2021;Â Larsen 2011;Â Watson 2016), one trial for 16 weeks (Wycherley 2010), three trials for six months (Sato 2017;Â Westman 2008;Â Yamada 2014), five trials for one year (Elhayany 2010;Â Hockaday 1978;Â Pedersen 2014;Â Samaha 2003;Â Saslow 2017a), and three trials for two years (Guldbrand 2012;Â Krebs 2012;Â Tay 2014). The results for only the active weightâreducing phases of diets in participants with T2DM were reported in comparison 3. RESULTS: Four of these trials also implemented a weightâmaintenance phase following their weightâreducing phase for 12 weeks (Watson 2016), nine months (Larsen 2011), 12 months (Sato 2017), and 21 months (Dyson 2007), and we reported these results in comparison 4. RESULTS: TheÂ Characteristics of included studiesÂ table contains key items from the template for intervention description and replication (TIDieR) checklist and guide (Hoffman 2014), including materials and procedures used to implement the diets; and who, how, where, and when the diets were implemented in each trial. RESULTS: Funding of included trials RESULTS: About 60% (n = 28) of the trials including participants without T2DM reported being funded only by nonâcommercial funders, including government and public research institutes, while 36% (n = 17) reported some or all funding by food/diet industry and related private companies, such as food and nutrition product manufacturers, organisations representing the interests of food producers (e.g. Pork Council, Dairy Farmers Association) and diet book and diet product organisations (Bales 2017;Â BenassiâEvans 2009;Â Dyson 2007;Â Farnsworth 2003;Â Frisch 2009;Â Griffin 2013;Â Josse 2011;Â Lasker 2008;Â Layman 2005;Â Layman 2009;Â Lean 1997;Â Liu 2013;Â Parr 2016;Â Racette 1995;Â Ruth 2013;Â Volek 2009;Â Wycherley 2012). Sources of funding were not reported by two trials in participants without T2DM (Aude 2004;Â Landers 2002). RESULTS: About a third of trials including participants with T2DM (38%; n = 6) were funded solely by nonâcommercial funders, with seven trials (41%) reporting some or all funding by food/diet industry and related private companies (Dyson 2007;Â Hockaday 1978;Â Larsen 2011;Â Sato 2017;Â Watson 2016;Â Westman 2008;Â Wycherley 2010), and three trials not reporting funding source (Elhayany 2010;Â Pedersen 2014;Â Yamada 2014). RESULTS: Excluded studies RESULTS: We contacted 64 corresponding authorsÂ forÂ further information to assist with study inclusion.Â We excludedÂ 323 fullâtext articles with reasons, as follows. The remaining referencesÂ whereÂ we could not reach the authors or information provided was not sufficient to make a clear judgement (n = 33), were includedÂ asÂ Studies awaiting classification. RESULTS: Risk of bias in included studies RESULTS: Risk of bias assessmentsÂ for each outcome included in the summary of findings tables, along with all domain judgements, are included in the forest plots.Â Figure 2Â provides our judgements about each risk of bias item presented as percentages across all included trials for bias arising from the randomisation process, and across all outcomes in the summary of findings tables for all other items using RoB 2. Additional information, such as support for judgements, is locatedÂ in theÂ risk of biasÂ section (located after theÂ Characteristics of ongoing studies).Â FIG: Risk of bias figure: systematic review authorsâ judgements about each risk of bias item presented as percentages across all included trials for bias arising from the randomisation process, and across all outcomes in the Summary of Findings tables for all other items using the Cochrane risk of bias 2 tool RESULTS: For most trials in participants without T2DM, the risk of bias arising from the randomisation process was judged as having 'some concerns' (n = 25), 10 trials were judged as low risk (Bales 2017;Â Dyson 2007;Â Ebbeling 2007;Â Gardner 2007;Â Griffin 2013;Â Haufe 2013;Â Jesudason 2013;Â Liu 2013;Â MarcoâBenedi 2019;Â Sacks 2009), and four trials as high risk for this domain (Keogh 2007;Â Parr 2016;Â Tay 2008;Â Wycherley 2012). The overall risk of bias of outcomes across trials in participants without T2DM was similar and predominantly high. High overall risk of bias judgements were mostly as a result of bias due to missing outcome data, with high proportions of missing outcome data in many trials and this not being adequately handled by recommended statistical approaches. Bias due to deviations from intended interventions also contributed to high overall risk of bias. Problems with the measurement of outcomes did not contribute to high overall risk as most outcomes were not subjective or observerâreported; the exception was constipation, which was participantâreported and judged as high risk for most of the trials. None of the trials for any outcome in participants without T2DM reported prespecified analysis intentions in sufficient detail to enable assessment of selection of the reported result. Three trials did not contribute any numeric data to metaâanalyses and risk of bias for these trials was not assessed, in line with guidance on implementing RoB 2 (Foster 2003;Â Pittas 2005;Â Racette 1995).Â Five trials did not report any outcomes included in the summary of findings tables, and we did not assess risk of bias of these (JuanolaâFalgarona 2014;Â Kitabchi 2013;Â Ruth 2013;Â Samaha 2003;Â Stentz 2016).Â RESULTS: Bias arising from the randomisation process was judged as low risk for approximately half of the trials in participants with T2DM (n = 8) (Dyson 2007;Â Evangelista 2021;Â Krebs 2012;Â Larsen 2011;Â Pedersen 2014;Â Saslow 2017a;Â Sato 2017;Â Watson 2016), with the remaining trials judged as having 'some concerns' (Elhayany 2010;Â Guldbrand 2012;Â Samaha 2003;Â Tay 2014;Â Westman 2008;Â Wycherley 2010;Â Yamada 2014). Across trials in participants with T2DM, the overall risk of bias of outcomes was similar and mostly high. As in the trials in participants without T2DM, the high overall risk of bias judgements were largely driven by bias due to missing outcome data, with high proportions of missing data not being adequately handled, and to a lesser extent by bias due to deviations from intended interventions. None of the trials in participants with T2DM reported prespecified analysis intentions in sufficient detail to enable us to assess the selection of the reported result. We did not assess risk of bias for one older study as it did not contribute usable data for an outcome included in the summary of findings tables (Hockaday 1978).Â RESULTS: Effects of interventions RESULTS: See: Table 1; Table 2; Table 3; Table 4 RESULTS: See:Â Table 1;Â Table 2;Â Table 3;Â Table 4. RESULTS: We analysed results from trials in overweight and obese participants without T2DM separately from those in participants with T2DM. We also separated analyses for weightâreducing phases of diets, and for weightâreducing phases followed by weightâmaintenance phases. We report here the effects on the prespecified outcomes according to the four comparisons resulting from these stratifications.Â RESULTS: We assessed the followâup periods for the various outcomes as short term (three to < 12 months) or long term (â¥ 12 months). The exact authorâreported followâup periods per outcome per trial appear as footnotes in each forest plot (i.e. using weeks, months or years). To summarise the followâup period applicable per outcome, we also reported the specific followâup range across all the trials that reported on that outcome. RESULTS: None of the included trials reported on the following outcomes for any of the four comparisons: allâcause mortality, cardiovascular mortality, nonâfatal myocardial infarction, nonâfatal stroke and diagnosis of T2DM.
