MA TABLE: BMI,â¨DBP, diastolic blood pressureâ¨HbA1c,â¨HDLâc, high density lipoproteinâcholesterolâ¨LDLâc, low density lipoproteinâcholesterolâ¨MA, metaâanalysisâ¨NR, not reportedâ¨SBP, systolic blood pressureâ¨T2DM, type 2 diabetes mellitusâ¨TC, total cholesterolâ¨TG, triglycerides RESULTS: Primary outcomes RESULTS: Change in body weight (kg) at three to < 12 months RESULTS: GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference in change in body weight over three to 8.5 months compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (moderateâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias).Â RESULTS: Average weight reductions from baseline over the short term ranged from 12.18 kg to 4.45 kg with lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets and from 11.34 kg to 2.3 kg with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in the 37 trials that reported this outcome. The metaâanalysis showed little to no difference in weight reduction on average between lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups (MD â1.07 kg, (95% confidence interval (CI) â1.55 to â0.59, I2 = 51%, 3286 participants, 37 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 1.1) over three to 8.5 months. This lack of a difference in effect was confirmed by sensitivity analyses, including only trials with 'some concerns' of bias overall (Analysis 1.6; no trials at overall low risk of bias), those at low risk of attrition bias (Analysis 1.7) and those without reported diet/food industry funding (Analysis 1.8).Â RESULTS: Subgrouping by similarity of energy prescription (Analysis 1.2), extent of carbohydrate restriction (Analysis 1.3), diagnosed cardiovascular event or disease at baseline (Analysis 1.4) or gender (Analysis 1.5) did not suggest important clinical differences in average effects between subgroups, with mean differences in weight reduction in overweight and obese participants at three to < 12 months ranging between 0.25 kg and 2.71 kg across the various subgroups. Subgrouping by similarity of energy prescription and extent of carbohydrate restriction explained some heterogeneity. Heterogeneity was reduced (I2 = 0%) in the subgroup including only trials with similar energy prescriptions/approaches to energy restriction in both diets, and in the subgroup including only trials investigating lowâcarbohydrate diets (> 50 g to 150 g per day or < 45% of total energy intake). We did not downgrade for inconsistency. The subgroup including only trials with no energy prescriptions or unrestricted energy prescriptions in both diets had small total numbers of participants (n < 400). This was also the case for the subgroup of trials only including men.Â RESULTS: Nine trials reported this outcome in an unusable format (e.g. in figures or as percentage change in weight from baseline) and usable data were not provided when authors were contacted (Table 8). The funnel plot (Figure 3) shows most trials had similar standard errors of intervention effect estimates limiting the ability to assess asymmetry. The mean difference in fixedâeffect analysis, which gives less weight to small studies (â0.91 kg, 95% CI â1.21 to â0.62), is similar to the mean difference in randomâeffects metaâanalysis (â1.07 kg, 95% CI â1.55 to â0.59,Â Analysis 1.1), which gives more weight to smaller studies, suggesting that any smallâstudy effects have little effect on the intervention effect estimate. FIG: Funnel plot for change in weight at 3 to < 12 months (Analysis 1.1) in comparison 1 RESULTS: Thirteen of the 37 trials had followâup at three months from baseline, nine at four months, 13 at six months, one at 26 weeks (about 6.5 months), and one trial at 34 weeks (about 8.5 months) RESULTS: Change in body weight (kg) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference to change in body weight over one to two years compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (moderateâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias). RESULTS: Longâterm average weight reductions in the 14 trials that reported this outcome ranged from 13.1 kg to 2.46 kg in lowâcarbohydrate diet groups and from 11.6 kg to 1.7 kg in balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in weight reduction between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one to two years (MD â0.93 kg, 95% CI â1.81 to â0.04, I2 = 40%, 1805 participants, 14 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 1.9). Sensitivity analyses including only trials at low risk of attrition bias (Analysis 1.10) and trials without diet/food industry funding confirmed this lack of a difference in effect (Analysis 1.11). Other planned sensitivity analyses included fewer than two studies and thus were not performed. RESULTS: Two trials reported this outcome in an unusable format (e.g. in figures or as percentage change in weight from baseline) and usable data were not provided when authors were contacted (Table 8). The funnel plot (Figure 4) suggests that smaller studies may be missing. The mean difference in fixedâeffect analysis, which gave less weight to small studies (â0.81 kg, 95% CI â1.43 to â0.19), was similar to the mean difference in the randomâeffects metaâanalysis (â0.93 kg, 95% CI â1.81 to â0.04,Â Analysis 1.9), which gave more weight to smaller studies, suggesting that any smallâstudy effects had little effect on the intervention effect estimate. FIG: Funnel plot for change in weight at â¥ 12 months (Analysis 1.9) in comparison 1 RESULTS: Ten of the 14 trials had followâup at one year, one at 15 months, one at 74 weeks (about 18.5 months), with the two longest trials having followâup at two years. RESULTS: Number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at three to < 12 months RESULTS: The number of participants achieving at least 5% weight loss over the short term in the three trials reporting this outcome ranged from 14 to 41 with lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets and from eight to 35 with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets. The metaâanalysis of the risk ratio (RR) of the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at three to six months was 1.30 (95% CI 1.00 to 1.68, I2 = 47%, 161 participants, 3 RCTs,Â Analysis 1.12) when comparing lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups. Two of the three trials that reported this outcome had followâup at three months and the other at six months. RESULTS: Number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: GRADE assessment suggests that the evidence is very uncertain about whether there is a difference in the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at one year, when comparing lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (very lowâcertainty evidence; downgraded once for risk of bias and twice for imprecision). RESULTS: Two studies reported on this outcome at one year (RR 1.11, 95% CI 0.94 to 1.31; IÂ² = 17%; 137 participants, 2 RCTs,Â very lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 1.13), with the number of participants achieving at least 5% weight loss ranging from 28 to 30 in the lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing group and from 27 to 29 in the balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing group. Another included trial also measured this outcome at two years but it was not reported in a usable format (Table 8).Â RESULTS: Secondary outcomes RESULTS: For comparison 1, no trials reported on the number of participants per group with reduction in BMI (kg/m2) of at least 5% at â¥ 12 months. RESULTS: Change in BMI (kg/m2) at three to < 12 months RESULTS: Twentyâone trials (n = 1517 participants) reported on shortâterm BMI change for comparison 1, with five of the 20 trials having followâup at three months, five at four months and 11 trials at six months. Across the trials, average reduction in BMI from baseline ranged from 4.7 kg/m2 to 1.8 kg/m2 with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from 3.7 kg/m2 to 0.98 kg/m2 with balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups. We did not pool these results into an overall effect estimate due to substantial heterogeneity (IÂ² = 53%, TauÂ² = 0.18; ChiÂ² = 42.52, df = 20 (P = 0.002)) but rather presented the individual effect sizes between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets per studyÂ (Analysis 1.14).Â RESULTS: Change in BMI (kg/m2) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: Average reduction in BMI from baseline over the long term in the five trials reporting this outcome ranged from 5.2 kg/m2 to 1.65 kg/m2 in lowâcarbohydrate diet groups and from 4.1 kg/m2 to 0.92 kg/m2 in balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups.Â When lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets were compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets, the difference in BMI change on average at one to two years was â0.61 kg/m2 (95% CI â0.99 to â0.23, I2 = 0%, 490 participants, 5 RCTs,Â Analysis 1.15). Four trials had followâup at one year and the remaining trial at two years. RESULTS: Number of participants per group with reduction in BMI (kg/m2) of at least 5% at three to < 12 months RESULTS: A single small study reported on this outcome at three months and the risk ratio was 1.57 (95% CI 0.79 to 3.12, 55 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 1.16) with 14 participants in the lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing group and eight participants in the balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing group achieving at least 5% reduction in BMI. RESULTS: Change in DBP (mmHg) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference to change in DBP compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets over one to two years in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (moderateâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias). RESULTS: Over one to two years, average change in DBP from baseline ranged from a 9 mmHg reduction to a 4 mmHg increase with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from an 11 mmHg reduction to 2.9 mmHg increase with balancedâcarbohydrate diets across the 11 trials that reported this. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in change in DBP between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one to two years (MD â0.09 mmHg, 95% CI â1.29 to 1.12, I2 = 44%, 1419 participants, 11 RCTs, moderateâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 1.17). Seven of the 11 trials had followâup at one year, one at 15 months, one at 18 months and the other two trials at two years. RESULTS: Change in SBP (mmHg) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: Average change in SBP from baseline in the 11 trials reporting this outcome ranged from reductions of 13.8 mmHg to 0.2 mmHg in lowâcarbohydrate diet groups and from a reduction of 14.6 mmHg to an increase of 1.7 mmHg in balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups over one to two years of followâup. For this comparison, the mean difference in change in SBP at one to two years was â1.37 mmHg (95% CI â2.99 to 0.24, I2 = 34%, 1397 participants, 11 RCTs,Â Analysis 1.18). Seven of the 11 trials had followâup at one year, one at 15 months, one at 18 months and the other two trials at two years. RESULTS: Change in LDL cholesterol (mmol/L) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference in change in LDL cholesterol over one to two years compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (moderateâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias). RESULTS: Over one to two years, average change in LDL cholesterol from baseline across the 13 trials that reported this outcome ranged from reduction of 0.3 mmol/L to an increase of 0.6 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from a reduction of 0.31 mmol/L to an increase of 0.1 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in change in LDL cholesterol between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one to two years (MD 0.04 mmol/L 95% CI â0.05 to 0.12, I2 = 33%, 1494 participants, 13 RCTs, moderateâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 1.19). Nine of the 13 trials had followâup at one year, one at 15 months, one at 18 months and the other two trials at two years. One of the included trials measured this outcome but it was not reported in a usable format (Table 8).Â RESULTS: Change in HDL cholesterol (mmol/L) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: Average change in HDL cholesterol from baseline over one to two years ranged from a reduction of 0.1 mmol/L to an increase of 0.3 mmol/L in lowâcarbohydrate diet groups and from a reduction of 0.21 mmol/L to an increase of 0.18 mmol/L in balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups in the 13 trials that reported this outcome. When lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets were compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets, the mean difference in change in HDL cholesterol at one to two years was 0.06 mmol/L (95% CI 0.02 to 0.10, I2 = 48%, 1519 participants, 13 RCTs,Â Analysis 1.20). Nine of the 13 trials had followâup at one year, one at 15 months, one at 18 months and the other two trials at two years. RESULTS: Change in nonâHDL cholesterol (mmol/L) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: Two small studies reported on this outcome at one year and the mean difference in nonâHDL cholesterol was 0.06 mmol/L (95% CI â0.2 to 0.33, I2 = 47%, 225 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 1.21) with average change in nonâHDL ranging from a reduction of 0.13 mmol/L to an increase of 0.24 mmol/L in lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing groups and average reductions ranging from 0.1 mmol/L to 0.02 mmol/L in balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing groups.Â RESULTS: Change in total cholesterol (mmol/L) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: Over one to two years, average change in total cholesterol from baseline ranged from a reduction of 0.4 mmol/L to an increase of 0.7 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from a reduction of 0.42 mmol/L to an increase of 0.13 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate diets across the 11 trials that reported this. On average, there was no difference in change in total cholesterol at one to two years between the two types of diet (MD 0.01 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.1 to 0.12, I2 = 41%, 1291 participants, 11 RCTs,Â Analysis 1.22). Eight of the 11 trials had followâup at one year, one at 15 months and the other two trials at two years. RESULTS: Change in triglycerides (mmol/L) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: Across the 13 trials that reported on triglycerides over one to two years, average change from baseline ranged from reductions of 0.58 mmol/L to 0.1 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from a reduction of 0.44 mmol/L to an increase of 0.02 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. For this comparison, the mean difference in change in triglycerides at one to two years was â0.11 mmol/L (95% CI â0.16 to â0.06, I2 = 0%, 1559 participants, 13 RCTs,Â Analysis 1.23). Nine of the 13 trials had followâup at one year, one at 15 months, one at 18 months and the other two trials at two years. RESULTS: Participantâreported adverse effects RESULTS: Participantâreported adverse effects were scantily reported by six included trials for comparison 1, with all outcomes except shortâterm constipation being reported only by single trials, and one of the trials reporting on most of these outcomes (Bazzano 2014). All 19 dichotomous outcomes reported very few events, had small total sample sizes and had wide 95% CIs. The four continuous outcomes all had small total samples sizes, mean differences close to 0 and wide 95% CIs. RESULTS: Gastrointestinal RESULTS: GRADE assessment suggests that the evidence is very uncertain about whether there is a difference in the number of participants per group with constipation at three to six months when comparing lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (very lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and twice for imprecision).Â RESULTS: The metaâanalysis of the risk ratio of the number of participants per group reporting constipation at three to six months was 1.06 (95% CI 0.81 to 1.38, I2 = 0%, 564 participants, 4 RCTs,Â very lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 1.24) when comparing the two diet groups.Â RESULTS: One trial reported constipation at one year (RR 0.63, 95% CI 0.32 to 1.25, 148 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 1.25). RESULTS: Two trials reported on events of diarrhoea finding no difference over the shorter term (at three months and at six months) (RR 0.98, 95% CI 0.33 to 2.93, 244 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 1.26) or at one year (RR 0.32, 95% CIÂ 0.03 to 3.05, 148 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 1.27). RESULTS: Appetite and hunger RESULTS: Appetite change was reported by one trial at six months followâup (RR 0.19, 95% CI 0.01 to 3.99, 148 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 1.36) and at one year (RR 0.49, 95% CI 0.05 to 5.25, 148 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 1.37). The mean score for hunger was â1.05 (SEM 0.56; n = 21) in the lowâcarbohydrate diet group and â0.18 (SEM 0.66; n = 15) in the balancedâcarbohydrate diet group. Mean scores for desire to eat were â1.02 (SEM 0.59; n = 21) in the lowâcarbohydrate diet group and â0.16 (SEM 0.76; n = 15) in the balancedâcarbohydrate diet group (Griffin 2013). RESULTS: Fatigue RESULTS: One trial reported on events offatigue at six months (RR 0.80, 95% CIÂ 0.47 to 1.36, 148 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 1.38) and at one year (RR 0.91, 95% CIÂ 0.49 to 1.71, 148 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 1.39). RESULTS: Â At four months followâup, one trial reported depressive symptoms according to the Beck Depression Inventory (MD â0.30, 95% CI â1.36 to 0.76, 217 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 1.45) and anxiety symptoms according to the StateâTrait Anxiety Inventory (MD â0.20, 95% CI â1.44 to 1.04, 217 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 1.46). Lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets versus balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (weightâreducing phase followed by weightâmaintenance phase) RESULTS: Table 2Â presents the effects of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (weightâreducing phase followed by weightâmaintenance phase) in overweight and obese participants without T2DM on longâterm (â¥ 12 months) changes in body weight, DBP and LDL cholesterol. RESULTS: Key details about studies in this comparison, including characteristics of the intervention, population, outcomes and method of synthesis are detailed in the OSIS table (Table 10). RESULTS: Primary outcomes RESULTS: The only primary outcome reported by the included trials for comparison 2 was change in body weight at â¥ 12 months. RESULTS: Change in body weight (kg) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase may result in little to no difference in change in body weight over one to two years compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and once for imprecision). RESULTS: Over the long term, average weight change from baseline ranged from a reduction of 5.4 kg to an increase of 0.86 kg with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from reductions of 5.5 kg to 1.5 kg with balancedâcarbohydrate diets across the three trials that reported this outcome. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in weight reduction between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one to two years (MD â0.30 kg, 95% CI â2.77 to 2.16, I2 = 0%, 73 participants, 3 RCTs,Â lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 2.1). One of the trials had a weightâreducing phase of 12 weeks followed by a weightâmaintenance phase of 40 weeks, measuring change in weight at one year. The other two trials measured change in weight at two years, with one trial testing a threeâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a 21âmonth maintenance phase, and the other trial testing a 6âmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a maintenanceâphase that averaged 18 months in duration. This lack of a difference in effect was confirmed by a sensitivity analysis including only the two trials without reported diet/food industry funding (MD â0.80 kg, 95% CI â3.48 to 1.88, I2 = 0%, 63 participants, 2 RCTs, analysis not shown).Â RESULTS: Secondary outcomes RESULTS: The only secondary outcomes reported by the included trials for comparison 2 were changes in DBP, SBP, LDL and HDL cholesterol, total cholesterol and triglycerides. Â RESULTS: Changes in DBP and SBP (mmHg) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: GRADE assessment suggests that the evidence is very uncertain about the effect of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase on change in DBP at one year in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (very lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and twice for imprecision). RESULTS: One very small trial compared these diets using a weightâreducing phase of 12 weeks followed by a maintenance phase of 40 weeks, and reported on changes in DBP (MD â6.0 mmHg, 95% CI â17.55 to 5.55, 13 participants, 1 RCT,Â very lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 2.2) and SBPÂ (MD â15.0 mmHg, 95% CI â32.36 to 2.36, 13 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 2.3) at one year. The study reported average DBP reductions from baseline of 4 mmHg in the lowâcarbohydrate diet group and of 6 mmHg in the balancedâcarbohydrate diet group. For SBP, the study reported an average decrease from baseline of 2 mmHg in the lowâcarbohydrate group and an increase of 2 mmHg in the balancedâcarbohydrate group. RESULTS: Changes in LDL, HDL and total cholesterol and triglycerides (mmol/L) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: Two small trials reported changes in these blood lipids at one to two years. GRADE assessment suggests that the evidence is very uncertain about the effect of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase on change in LDL at one to two years in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (very lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and twice for imprecision). RESULTS: One trial used a weightâreducing phase of 12 weeks followed by a maintenance phase of 40 weeks, and the other trial used a weightâreducing phase of six months followed by a maintenance phase of 18 months with changes reported at one and two years, respectively for LDL cholesterol (MD â0.08 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.44 to 0.28, I2 = 0%, 56 participants, 2 RCTs, very lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 2.4), HDL cholesterol (MD â0.05 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.37 to 0.28, I2 = 5%, 56 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 2.5), total cholesterol (MD â0.08 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.43 to 0.27, I2 = 0%, 56 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 2.6) and triglycerides (MD â0.08 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.34 to 0.17, I2 = 0%, 56 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 2.7).Â RESULTS: Average LDL cholesterol reductions from baseline ranged from 0.79 mmol/L to 0.2 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from 1.15 mmol/L to 0.14 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. For HDLâcholesterol, average changes ranged from a decrease of 0.2 mmol/L to an increase of 0.11 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from increases of 0.03 mmol/L to 0.04 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. Average reductions in total cholesterol ranged from 0.24 mmol/L to 0.79 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from 0.17 mmol/L to 1.14 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. For triglycerides, average reductions ranged from 0.19 mmol/L to 0.28 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from 0.04 mmol/L to 0.13 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. Lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets versus balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (weightâloss phase only) RESULTS: Table 3Â presents the effects of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (weightâreducing phase only) in overweight and obese participants with T2DM on shortâterm (three to < 12 months) and longâterm (â¥ 12 months) changes in body weight, as well as on the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% over the long term, longâterm change in DBP, HbA1c and LDL cholesterol, and shortâterm constipation. RESULTS: Key details about studies in this comparison, including characteristics of the intervention, population, outcomes and method of synthesis can be found in the OSIS table (Table 10). RESULTS: Primary outcomes RESULTS: Change in body weight (kg) at three to < 12 months RESULTS: GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference in change in body weight over three to six months compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (moderateâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias). RESULTS: Average weight reductions from baseline over three to six months ranged from 12 kg to 2.41 kg with lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets and from 11.5 kg to 0.33 kg with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in the 14 trials reporting this outcome. The metaâanalysis showed little to no difference in weight reduction on average between lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups over three to six months (MD â1.26 kg, 95% CI â2.44 to â0.09, I2 = 47%, 1114 participants, 14 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 3.1). This lack of a difference in effect was also seen with sensitivity analyses including only trials with 'some concerns' of bias overall (Analysis 3.2, no trials at overall low risk of bias), at low risk of attrition bias (Analysis 3.3) and without reported diet/food industry funding (Analysis 3.4).Â RESULTS: One included trial also measured change in body weight at three to < 12 months but reported it in an unusable format (Table 9). The funnel plot (Figure 5) suggests that smaller studies may be missing. The mean difference in fixedâeffect analysis, which gives less weight to small studies (â0.92 kg, 95% CI â1.65 to â0.19), is similar to the mean difference in randomâeffects metaâanalysis (â1.26 kg, 95% CI â2.44 to â0.09,Â Analysis 3.1), which gives more weight to smaller studies, suggesting that any smallâstudy effects have little effect on the intervention effect estimate. The oldest included trial also measured change in body weight at â¥ 12 months but reported it in an unusable format (Table 9).Â RESULTS: Number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at three to < 12 months RESULTS: A single small study reported on this outcome at three months and the risk ratio was 1.01 (95% CI 0.77 to 1.33, 45 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 3.7) with 19 participants in the lowâcarbohydrate group and 18 participants in the balancedâcarbohydrate group achieving at least 5% weight loss from baseline. RESULTS: Key details about studies in this comparison, including characteristics of the intervention, population, outcomes and method of synthesis are detailed in the OSIS table (Table 10). RESULTS: Primary outcomes RESULTS: The only primary outcomes reported by the included trials for comparison 4 were change in body weight at three to < 12 months and change in body weight at â¥ 12 months.Â RESULTS: Change in body weight (kg) at three to < 12 months RESULTS: GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase may result in little to no difference in change in body weight at six months compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and once for imprecision). RESULTS: The single study reporting change in weight at six months found average weight reductions of 1 kg with the lowâcarbohydrate diet and 0.2 kg with the balancedâcarbohydrate diet. The mean difference in weight reduction between the two diets in this study demonstrated little to no difference at six months (MD â0.80 kg, 95% CI â2.46 to 0.86, 61 participants, 1 RCT,Â lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 4.1). This trial tested diets with a threeâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a threeâmonth weightâmaintenance phase. RESULTS: Change in body weight (kg) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase may result in little to no difference in change in body weight over one to two years compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and once for imprecision). RESULTS: Average changes in weight from baseline over one to two years in the three trials reporting this outcome ranged from a reduction of 2.23 kg to an increase 1.3 kg with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from reductions of 2.17 kg to 1.5 kg with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in weight reduction between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one to two years (MD â0.07 kg, 95% CI â1.31 to 1.17, IÂ² = 0%, 158 participants, 3 RCTs,Â lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 4.2). The shortest of the trials measured change in weight at one year with the diets having a threeâmonth weightâloss phase followed by a nineâmonth weightâreducing phase. The second trial had followâup at 18 months and tested diets with a sixâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a 12âmonth maintenance phase. The third trial had followâup at two years, and tested diets with a threeâmonth weightâreducing followed by a 21âmonth weightâmaintenance phase. All trials had high risk of attrition bias and overall bias, and had diet/food industry funding, precluding sensitivity analyses.Â RESULTS: Secondary outcomes RESULTS: The secondary outcomes reported by the included trials for comparison 4 were change in BMI at three to < 12 months, change in BMI at â¥ 12 months, change in HbA1c, DBP, SBP, LDL and HDL cholesterol, total cholesterol and triglycerides. Â RESULTS: Change in BMI (kg/m2) at three to < 12 months RESULTS: One trial compared these diets using a threeâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a threeâmonth weightâmaintenance phase and reported average BMI reductions from baseline of 0.3 kg/m2 in the lowâcarbohydrate group and 0.01 kg/m2 in the balancedâcarbohydrate group after six months. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in BMI change at six months was â0.29 kg/m2 (95% CI â0.83 to 0.25, 61 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 4.3).Â RESULTS: Change in BMI (kg/m2) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: The single trial reporting on this outcome in comparison 4 found average BMI reductions from baseline of 0.75 kg/m2 with the lowâcarbohydrate diet and 0.63 kg/m2 with the balanced diet after 18 months (sixâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by 12âmonth weightâmaintenance phase). The mean difference in BMI change at 18 months in this trial was â0.12 kg/m2 (95% CI â0.86 to 0.62, 47 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 4.4). RESULTS: Changes in DBP and SBP (mmHg) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: GRADE assessment suggests that the evidence is very uncertain about the effect of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase on change in DBP at one year in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (very lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and twice for imprecision). RESULTS: One trial compared these diets in comparison 4 using a threeâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a nineâmonth maintenance phase, and reported on changes in DBP (MD â0.44 mmHg, 95% CI â4.89 to 4.01, 99 participants, 1 RCT,Â very lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 4.5) and SBPÂ (MD â4.27 mmHg, 95% CI â8.74 to 0.20, 99 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 4.6) at one year. The study reported average DBP increases from a baseline of 0.21 mmHg in the lowâcarbohydrate diet group and of 0.65 mmHg in the balancedâcarbohydrate diet group at one year. For SBP, the study reported an average decrease from baseline of 5.03 mmHg in the lowâcarbohydrate group and 0.76 mmHg in the balancedâcarbohydrate group. RESULTS: Change in HbA1c (%) at 12 months RESULTS: GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase may result in little to no difference in change in HbA1c over one to two years compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and once for imprecision). RESULTS: Average changes in HbA1c from baseline over one to two years in the three trials reporting this outcome ranged from a reduction of 0.39% to an increase of 0.3% with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from a reduction of 0.37% to an increase of 0.4% with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in change in HbA1c between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one to two years (MD 0.02%, 95% CI â0.30 to 0.33, IÂ² = 0%, 160 participants, 3 RCTs,Â lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 4.7). The shortest of the trials measured change in HbA1c at one year with diets having a threeâmonth weightâloss phase followed by a nineâmonth weightâreducing phase. The second trial had followâup at 18 months and tested diets with a sixâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a 12âmonth maintenance phase. The third trial had followâup at two years, and tested diets with a threeâmonth weightâreducing followed by a 21âmonth weightâmaintenance phase. RESULTS: Change in LDL, HDL and total cholesterol and triglycerides (mmol/L) at â¥ 12 months RESULTS: Two trials reported changes in these blood lipids at one to two years. GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase may result in little to no difference in change in LDL over one year to 18 months compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and once for imprecision). RESULTS: One trial had followâup at one year with diets having a threeâmonth weightâloss phase followed by a nineâmonth weightâreducing phase. The other trial assessed followâup at 18 months and tested diets with a sixâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a 12âmonth maintenance phase.Â The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in change in LDL cholesterol between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one year to 18 months (MD â0.06 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.26 to 0.13, IÂ² = 0%, 145 participants, 2 RCTs,Â lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 4.8). The two trials reported on HDL cholesterol (MD 0.0 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.07 to 0.08, IÂ² = 0%, 148 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 4.9) and triglycerides (MD â0.06 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.45 to 0.32, IÂ² = 0%, 148 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 4.11), while only one of the trials reported on total cholesterol at one year (MD â0.16 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.51 to 0.19, 99 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 4.10).Â RESULTS: Average changes in LDL cholesterol over one year to 18 months in the two trials ranged from reductions of 0.2 mmol/L to 0.05 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from a reduction of 0.17 mmol/L to an increase of 0.04 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. For HDL cholesterol, average increases over this period ranged from 0.04 mmol/L to 0.08 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets and from 0.03 mmol/L to 0.08 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets. Average changes in total cholesterol at one year reported by the single study ranged from a reduction of 0.15 mmol/L in the lowâcarbohydrate group to an increase of 0.01 mmol/L in the balancedâcarbohydrate group. For triglycerides, average changes over one year to 18 months in the two trials ranged from a reduction of 0.47 mmol/L to an increase of 0.07 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from reductions of 0.3 mmol/L to 0.05 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. RESULTS: Participantâreported adverse effectsÂ RESULTS: Two adverse effects were reported by a single trial in comparison 4 (Watson 2016). This trial reported on anxiety at six months using the 'Anxiety and worry' subscale of the Dâ39 diabetes QoL questionnaire, but did not report sample sizes per group. The mean score in the lowâcarbohydrate diet group was 33.91 (SE 3.55) and in the balanced diet group was 31.43 (SE 3.71). Fatigue at six months was also reported on by this trial using the 'Energy and mobility' subscale of the Dâ39 diabetes QoL questionnaire. The mean score in the lowâcarbohydrate diet group was 22.04 (SE 2.49) and in the balanced diet group was 23.28 (SE 2.61), with no sample sizes being reported per group. DISCUSS: Discussion DISCUSS: Summary of main results DISCUSS: This review examined the effects of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets compared to 'balanced'âcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets on weight and cardiovascular risk factors. We used approaches aimed at addressing factors that may limit interpretation in other similar reviews. These included explicit criteria for the compositions and intentions of the treatment and control diets, stratifying findings in participants without and with T2DM, separating findings from weightâreducing and weightâmaintenance phases of diets, meaningful and comparable followâup periods, comprehensive searches, and multiple efforts to obtain and include all relevant and necessary data and information not reported in published papers; as well as assessing the certainty of this evidence using GRADE. To our knowledge, this review includes the largest number of trials that have examined this question to date. DISCUSS: Lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (weightâreducing phases only) DISCUSS: Participants without and with T2DM in both lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups reduced their weight to varying degrees in the short term (range of weight reduction across both diets: 12.2 to 0.33 kg) and long term (range of weight reduction across both diets: 13.1 to 1.7 kg). We considered a loss of at least 5% of initial weight to be clinically meaningful, and a weight change that could reasonably be expected in our minimum diet duration of 12 weeks. Thus, reductions from around the middle of these ranges (about 4 to 6 kg in most trials) would start to become clinically meaningful and translate to improvements in cardio metabolic health (Brown 2016;Â Franz 2015;Â Jensen 2014;Â Truby 2006;Â Wald 2012;Â Wing 2010).Â DISCUSS: Notably, in overweight and obese participants without and with T2DM, the metaâanalyses showed little or no difference between the effects of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets and balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets on weight reduction over three to 8.5 months (short term), with mean differences in weight reduction of about one kilogram. This was also the case over one to two years (long term), with mean differences in weight reduction of less than one kilogram. The 95% CIs of pooled mean differences in shortâ and longâterm weight change did not include appreciable harm or benefit (ranging from 2.44 kg lower to 1.46 kg higher), and we therefore did not downgrade for imprecision. The lack of differences found in effects on weight reduction were confirmed by sensitivity analyses. There was, however, some heterogeneity in effects in participants without T2DM over the short term. Subgrouping by similarity of energy prescription, extent of carbohydrate restriction, diagnosed cardiovascular event or disease at baseline or gender did not suggest important clinical differences in average effects between the various subgroups. Mean differences in weight reduction between diet groups across the various subgroups at the short term ranged between 0.25 kg and 2.71 kg. Some heterogeneity could be explained by subgrouping studies according to similarity of energy prescription and extent of carbohydrate restriction.Â DISCUSS: We do not know whether there is a difference in the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at the long term since only one trial (n = 68) in men, judged as being at high risk of bias, reported on this outcome. DISCUSS: For mean changes in DBP at one to two years, some trials reported reductions and other trials reported increases in both diet groups in participants without and with T2DM (range of mean change across diet groups: â11 to 4.3 mmHg). In all participants, metaâanalyses showed little or no difference between the effects of the two diets on changes in DBP at one to two years, with mean differences of less than 0.5 mmHg. The 95% CIs of these pooled mean differences did not include appreciable harm or benefit (ranging from 1.84 mmHg lower to 1.28 mmHg higher) and we did not downgrade for imprecision. We considered changes in DBP of greater than 2 mmHg to be clinically meaningful (Whelton 2002). DISCUSS: At one to two years in both diet groups, some trials reported reductions in LDL cholesterol and others reported increases in participants without and with T2DM (range of mean change across diet groups: â0.61 to 0.6 mmol/L). Metaâanalyses showed little or no difference between the effects of the two diets on changes in LDL cholesterol at one to two years in all participants, with mean differences of up to 0.1 mmol/L. The 95% CIs of these pooled mean differences did not include appreciable harm or benefit (ranging from 0.05 mmol/L lower to 0.26 mmol/L higher) and we did not downgrade for imprecision. We considered changes in LDL cholesterol of greater than 0.26 mmol/L to be clinically meaningful (FernandezâFrieraÂ 2017;Â Howard 2000). DISCUSS: At one to two years, some trials in participants with T2DM reported reductions in HbA1c and others reported small increases in HbA1c in both diet groups (range of change across diet groups: â2% to 0.2%). Pooling these mean differences found little or no difference between the effects of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets versus balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets on change in HbA1c over one to two years in overweight and obese participants with T2DM, with a mean difference of 0.14%. The 95% CI of the pooled mean difference did not include appreciable harm or benefit (0.38% lower to 0.1% higher) and we did not downgrade for imprecision. We considered changes in HbA1c of greater than 0.5% to be clinically meaningful (NICE 2015). DISCUSS: Participantâreported adverse effects were poorly reported. In the few trials where these were reported, the effects included constipation, which we regarded as a patientâimportant adverse effect since it is frequently reported by people following lowâcarbohydrate diets. These limited data mean that we are very uncertain about whether there is a difference in the number of participants per diet group with constipation at three to six months in all participants. DISCUSS: Lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (weightâreducing phase followed by weightâmaintenance phase) DISCUSS: Evidence about the comparative effects of diets from studies using weightâreducing phases followed by weightâmaintenance phases was limited. Only eight trials reported these data for some outcomes, and one of these trials did not contribute any numeric data to metaâanalyses. All the trials applied different approaches and time frames to the weightâmaintenance phases of the diets, with the shortest weightâmaintenance phase being six weeks and the longest being 21 months. Findings were similar to the comparisons that included only weightâreducing phases of the two diets, but our certainty in these findings was lower, largely due to imprecision, with small total sample sizes and wide 95% CIs around the pooled estimates.Â DISCUSS: In overweight and obese participants without T2DM, metaâanalyses showed that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets including a weightâmaintenance phase may result in little or no difference in change in weight over one to two years compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets including a weightâmaintenance phase. We are very uncertain about whether there are differences in effects on DBP and LDL cholesterol between the two diets in these participants. None of the eight trials reported usable data for the other outcomes in our summary of findings table.Â DISCUSS: In overweight and obese participants with T2DM, metaâanalyses showed that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets including a weightâmaintenance phase may result in little or no difference in change in weight at six months, and at one to two years, compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets including a weightâmaintenance phase. This was also the case for change in HbA1c and LDL cholesterol. We are very uncertain about whether there are differences in effects on DBP between the two diets in these participants. None of the eight trials reported usable data for the other outcomes in our summary of findings table. DISCUSS: Overall completeness and applicability of evidence DISCUSS: Our review employed a comprehensive search strategy with no language restrictions to identify all RCTs assessing the effects of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets on weight and cardiovascular risk in overweight and obese adults without or with T2DM. We tapped multiple sources of information for all trials and contacted study authors multiple times in all cases where we needed additional data or information. This included requesting information from 30 author teams to enable clear judgements and reporting related to eligibility, stratification, risk of bias, as well as numeric data to enable the inclusion of as much usable data in metaâanalyses as we could obtain.Â DISCUSS: We prespecified outcomes at defined lengths of followâup to examine possible differences in effects over time. No trials reported on outcomes after two years, and 60% of trials had a duration of six months or less. Change in body weight was reported by most trials, but few studies trials reported on the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% from baseline. Despite multiple attempts, we were not unable to obtain and include weight change data from 11 trials, as they reported data in unusable formats.Â DISCUSS: None of the trials reported on allâcause mortality, cardiovascular mortality, nonâfatal myocardial infarction, nonâfatal stroke and diagnosis of T2DM. This is to be expectedÂ to some degree in view of the practical challenges posed by long durations of followâup in weightâreducing diet trials.Â Pooled data from longâterm prospective cohort studies on dietary carbohydrate intake and mortality have demonstrated harm at the extremes of intake (Seidelmann 2018). Moreover, a range of potential shorterâ and longerâterm safety concerns of lowâcarbohydrate diets have been discussed in recent papers, such as reduced dietary intake of fibre, minerals, vitamins, trace elements and polyunsaturated fats, unknown effects of longâterm ketosis, harmful environmental impacts and dysbiosis (Barber 2021;Â Sievenpiper 2020).Â DISCUSS: The effect of weight reduction per se on cardiovascular risk factors is also important for interpreting this evidence, as it is known that a weight reduction of 5% or more is associated with improvements in cardio metabolic risks, including blood lipids, blood pressure and HbA1c (Brown 2016;Â Franz 2015). As we found little to no difference in weight reduction between lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets up to two years, one would reasonably not expect to find meaningful differences in effects on blood lipids, blood pressure and HbA1c between the two diets, which was the case in our review. DISCUSS: Our review did not seek to address effects of differences in the quality of dietary carbohydrates, or the quality of the replacement macronutrients (e.g. fat). Both quality and quantity or proportions are vital components of understanding the effects of macronutrients on health outcomes (Abdelhamid 2018;Â Barber 2021;Â Hooper 2020;Â Reynolds 2019;Â Sievenpiper 2020).Â DISCUSS: A criticism of examining mean differences in weight between diet groups is that they do not fully account for true different individual responses, where âtrueâ refers to individual response differences that are not a result of random trialâtoâtrial variability. In the context of 'personalised' nutrition, there is interest in ascertaining whether there are true individual differences in the responses to weightâreducing diets large enough to be clinically relevant. A recent systematic review, using a response variance comparison approach, examined whether the weight responses to lowâcarbohydrate diets or lowâfat diets (typically, balancedâcarbohydrate diets) differ between individuals, and was unable to detect clinically relevant differences in individual response heterogeneity between the two diets (Smith 2020). DISCUSS: All except one of the 61 trials were conducted in highâincome countries. There are, however, no obvious reasons to expect the effects of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets on body weight to be different in people from lowâ and middleâincome countries. High costs of lowâcarbohydrate diets and disproportionate financial effects on lower socioeconomic groups, which are beyond the scope of our review, have been covered elsewhere (Barber 2021;Â Raffensperger 2008). DISCUSS: Nearly 40% of included trials reported some or all funding by food/diet industry and related private companies, such as food and nutrition product manufacturers, organisations representing the interests of food producers (e.g. Pork Council, Dairy Farmers Association) and diet book and diet product organisations. DISCUSS: There are many individual and environmental factors that influence a person's ability to adhere to weightâreducing diets, and studies have shown that adherence to weightâreducing diets is one of the major factors that determine success over the short and long term (Gibson 2017). Systematic reviews and RCTs of lowâ and balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets have demonstrated that adherence is a problem, and reduces over time with both diets, with some of these specifically reporting difficulty with adhering to severely carbohydrateârestricted diets over the long term (Foster 2003;Â Gibson 2017;Â Ross 2021;Â Sacks 2009). We did not investigate the possible influence of adherence on the effects of the dietary interventions. However, we did extract information on fidelity for both diets (Characteristics of included studies), i.e. the degree to which an intervention happened in the way the investigators intended it to (Hoffman 2014).Â DISCUSS: Quality of the evidence DISCUSS: The interpretation of most weight reduction trials is constrained by small samples, a lack of blinding, and large loss to followâup (SimonsâMorton 2006), which were also observed across the trials in our review. None of the trials in the review were judged as having low risk of bias overall. The overall risk of bias of outcomes across trials in participants without and with T2DM was predominantly high, largely due to high proportions of missing outcome data in many trials. DISCUSS: Potential biases in the review process DISCUSS: The review may be affected by nonâreporting bias. For the 'known unknowns' (particular results from a trial not reported in a usable format), we contacted trial authors multiple times to obtain the data in a usable format. Failure to obtain this and consequent exclusion thereof is a limitation of the review process, as we cannot be absolutely certain if and how the inclusion of these data would have affected the pooled estimates. However, given the agreement in pooled mean differences in weight reduction between our review and other similar reviews, we think it is unlikely that these data would have meaningfully changed our pooled estimates. It was harder to make a judgement about the 'unknown unknowns' (entire eligible trials not reported or picked up by our comprehensive searching), but it is possible that small unpublished trials are missing. Interpreting funnel plot asymmetry was challenging since many trials had similar standard errors.Â DISCUSS: We excluded RCTs of less than 12 weeks' duration which may have been relevant to the review question. The reason for choosing only trials with at least 12 weeks followâup was to allow sufficient time to detect clinically meaningful weight and cardiovascular risk factor changes.Â DISCUSS: Agreements and disagreements with other studies or reviews DISCUSS: Pooled mean differences in weight reduction and cardiovascular risk factors in our review are in line with a number of recent systematic reviews with pairwise metaâanalyses (Chawla 2020;Â Dong 2020;Â Smith 2020;Â Yang 2021), and an older review with network metaâanalyses (Johnston 2014), in participants without T2DM. This is also the case for recent similar reviews in participants with T2DM (Meng 2017;Â Silverii 2020;Â Snorgaard 2017;Â Van Zuuren 2018). Systematic reviews with varying definitions of lowâcarbohydrate diets and differing eligibility criteria have shown that lowâcarbohydrate diets do not result in superior longâterm clinically meaningful weight reduction. An overview of systematic reviewsÂ of RCTs comparing lowâcarbohydrate to control diets (lowâfat or energyârestricted) in adults with overweight and obesity includedÂ 12 reviews (10 with metaâanalyses) and reported an inverse relationship between number of trial participants and the size of differences in weight loss (Churuangsuk 2018). CONCL: Authors' conclusions CONCL: Implications for practice CONCL: The small pooled mean differences in weight reduction between the diets (about 1 to 2 kg), while statistically significant in the short term, were not clinically important in the short or long term in an overweight and obese adult, without or with T2DM (lowâto moderateâcertainty evidence). These differences are similar to typical ranges of biological weight fluctuations over time (Liska 2019;Â Vuorinen 2021), and can at least in part be ascribed to biological weight fluctuations, which are influenced by various factors including level of activity, hydration status, season and medications. When interpreting the sizes of the mean differences of weight reduction between the two diets, one should also consider the total body water loss (2 to 3 kg) that follows dietary carbohydrate restriction due to dietâinduced diuresis from glycogen depletion and production of ketone bodies, which is restored when carbohydrates are eaten again (Denke 2001;Â Yang 1976).Â CONCL: Our systematic review failed to show that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets are superior to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets, with little or no difference in weight reduction and cardiovascular risk factors over the short (three to 8.5 months) and long term (one to two years). Trials did not report on our prespecified outcomes after two years of followâup. The range of potential safety concerns of lowâcarbohydrate diets not addressed in this review over the short and longer term should also be considered.Â CONCL: Most trials included participants without diagnosed cardiovascular disease or events at baseline, and average baseline LDL cholesterol concentrations and DBP across the trials were within the normal ranges defined for people without coronary artery disease. In people with lipid disorders and variability with atherogenic lipoprotein response, caution in recommending lowâcarbohydrate and consequent highâfat diets is warranted. Evidence on participantâreported adverse effects over two years was limited and we could not draw any conclusions about these. CONCL: Dietary modification is central to weight reduction, however, in view of the complex aetiology of obesity, it is important to consider the demonstrated value of combining diet and other positive lifestyle and behavioural interventions to reduce weight and cardiovascular risk. Current dietary guidance allows for flexibility in the proportion of macronutrients, including a wide range of carbohydrate intakes, with greater emphasis on quality over quantity and on total dietary patterns over single nutrients.Â CONCL: Implications for research CONCL: In view of the challenges associated with weightâreducing diet trials and the similar findings from this and other comparable reviews, it could reasonably be argued that additional trials on this question are not needed. However, the effects of lowâcarbohydrate diets compared to balancedâcarbohydrate diets beyond two years is unknown. If conducted, future trials on this question in participants without and with T2DM, should be longer than two years, adequately powered with greater attention to methodological quality, and specifically the use of more appropriate and rigorous statistical approaches to address loss to followâup, where relevant. Prospective registration, publication of protocols and of detailed data analysis plans, as well as use of appropriate reporting guidelines (e.g. CONSORT) by future trials, would also be beneficial to the quality and utility of any future research. Other key research areas related to dietary interventions for weightâreduction and cardiovascular health include improving dietary adherence, which is critical to both shortâ and longâterm weight loss, total dietary patterns and macronutrient quality.Â CONCL: History CONCL: Protocol first published: Issue 5, 2019 CONCL: Risk of bias TABLE: Risk of bias for analysis 1.1 Change in body weight (kg) at 3 to < 12 months TABLE: Study	Bias	 	Randomisation process	Deviations from intended interventions	Missing outcome data	Measurement of the outcome	Selection of the reported results	Overall	 	Authors' judgement	Support for judgement	Authors' judgement	Support for judgement	Authors' judgement	Support for judgement	Authors' judgement	Support for judgement	Authors' judgement	Support for judgement	Authors' judgement	Support for judgement	 	Aude 2004	Some concerns	Randomisation was done using a block design by sex to achieve an equal sex distribution. NoRecipients: N = 75 of which N = 66 (88%) female, mean (SD) age 45.8 (9.9) years, mean (SD) weight 96.3 (12.7) kg, mean (SD) BMI 35.2 (3.8) kg/m2, mean (SD) waist circumference 108.4 (9.3) cm, mean (SD) systolic BP 120.3 (12.8) mmHg, mean (SD) diastolic BP 77.5 (9.0) mmHg, mean (SD) total cholesterol 5.1 (1.1) mmol/L, mean (SD) LDL 3.2(0.9) mmol/L, mean (SD) HDL 1.4 (0.3) mmol/L, mean (SD) triglycerides 1.3 (0.6) mmol/L, mean (SD) plasma glucose 5.2 (0.6) mmol/L.Why? "Few randomized, controlled trials thus far have examined the effects of carbohydrate restriction on CVD risk factors in a diverse population with a significant proportion of black persons."What (materials)? "A handbook was given to participants that contained recipes, sample menus for 1 week of food intake at various energy levels, food lists, shopping lists, meal planners, and guides on counting macronutrients and reading nutrition labels. Participants assigned to the lowâcarbohydrate diet were instructed to maintain an intake of digestible carbohydrate (total carbohydrate minus total fiber) of less than 40 g/d. Dietary advice as per the "National Cholesterol Education Program guidelines". Neither diet included a specific calorie or energy goal. Participants in each group were asked to refrain from changing their physical activity levels during the intervention. Meetings were conducted with the dietitian weekly then monthly for the study period; these meetings were initially individualised and then group wise. Dietary recalls were also conducted to reflection on consumption over weekday and weekend.Who provided? Dietitian conducted the counselling sessions and all dietary recalls were obtained by a trained and certified staff member.How and where? Faceâtoâface at the Tulane University Health Sciences Center in New Orleans, LouisianaWhen and how much? "Participants met with a dietitian in weekly individual counseling sessions for the first 4 weeks, followed by small group counseling sessions every other week for the next 5 months (a total of 10 sessions) and monthly for the last 6 months of the intervention period. Individual sessions generally lasted about 1 hour and included dietary instruction and supportive counseling. Group counseling sessions were held separately for participants in the lowâfat and lowâcarbohydrate groups but followed a common behavioral curriculum."Strategies to improve or maintain fidelity; tailoring and modification: Trained and certified staff, single calibrated scales, standard procedures for allExtent of intervention fidelity: NRConcomitant interventions: N = 21 (28%) on antihypertensive meds, N = 12 (16%) were on lipidâlowering meds.Control diet:Name (as reported) and brief description: Lowâfat diet. "Increased consumption of fat, particularly saturated fat, has been linked to increased plasma concentrations of lipids, insulin resistance, glucose intolerance, and obesity. Therefore, it is possible that many Americans could actually suffer adverse health effects by using very low carbohydrate diets in an attempt to lose weight."What (materials)? Selfâtesting kits for ketosis, cooking tips, food diaries and pedometers (worn for 3 days a week). No specific exercise routineWhat (procedures)? Participants were instructed to follow an ad libitum diet with a maximum intake of 20 g carbohydrate. It was anticipated that this diet would induce ketosis. After 2 wk of dieting, subjects were permitted to increase their intake of carbohydrate to 40â60 g/d only if selfâtesting of urinary ketones continued to indicate ketosis. Group meetings addressed cooking tips, stress management, behaviour modification, and relapse prevention. On alternating weeks, individual counselling sessions took place where the dietitian reviewed their 3âd food records from the previous week and provided dietary recommendations and positive reinforcement. Subjects were advised to continue their baseline level of activity. At the end of the 3âmonth intervention, subjects were instructed to continue with their weight loss efforts, but without scheduled contact with the dietitians until the 6âmonth assessment.Who provided? "Diets with a high glycemic load (the mathematical product of the glycemic index and the carbohydrate amount) result in higher postprandial insulin concentration, calorie for calorie, than those with a low glycemic load." Individuals with a high insulin response to glucose may be most sensitive to the effects of glycemic load. The purpose of this study was to determine whether insulin secretion affects body fat loss among obese individuals consuming selfâprepared diets.What (materials)? "Participants were equipped with foodâchoice lists that delineated products into lowâ,moderateâ, and highâglycemic load categories. Registered dietitians provided information during cooking demonstrations to encourage consumption of lowâglycemic load foods and led interactive activities using food models to define appropriate serving sizes of highâglycemic load foods (e.g. refined grain products, sweets)."What (procedures)? Participants were counselled to consume lowâglycemic load foods (particularly nonstarchy vegetables, legumes, and temperate fruits) and to limit intake of highâglycemic load foods (such as refined grains, starchy vegetables, fruit juices, and sweets). Attention also was directed toward consuming sources of healthful fat including nuts, seeds, and oils. The target macronutrient composition was 40% of energy from carbohydrate, emphasising lowâglycemic index sources, 35% from fat, and 25% from protein. Nutrition education and dietary counselling were provided to participants. Registered dietitians provided information during cooking demonstrations to encourage consumption of lowâglycemic load foods and led interactive activities using food models to define appropriate serving sizes. 23 group workshops and 1 private counselling session each one for an hour as well as 5 motivational telephone calls for 30 mins each were conducted. Six of the group workshops were scheduled during the first 2 months of the intervention period, and the remaining workshops were held on a monthly basis thereafter. The private session occurred during the initial month, and a telephone call was scheduled for each of the subsequent 5 months of the intensive intervention period. Participants were asked to keep one 3âday food diary prior to each workshop, particularly during the intensive intervention period. Three unannounced telephoneâadministered 24âhour recall interviews were conducted at baseline and again at 6, 12, and 18 months to assess diet and physical activity.Who provided? Registered dietitianHow and where? Faceâtoâface group sessions as well as private sessions, location NRWhen and how much? "There were 23 group workshops (1 hour each), 1 private counseling session (1 hour), and 5 motivational telephone calls (30 minutes each). Six of the group workshops were scheduled during the first 2 months of the intervention period, and the remaining workshops were held on a monthly basis thereafter. The private session occurred during the initial month, and a telephone call was scheduled for each of the subsequent 5 months of the intensive intervention period."Strategies to improve or maintain fidelity; tailoring and modification: "Principles of nonformal adult education and participant centered counseling were applied to promote adherence to the diets. Respectful consideration of participant perspectives, core values, life experiences, current circumstances, and available resources formed a foundation for education and counseling. Participants were asked to keep a food diary (prior to each workshop). Dietitians prepared written feedback on submitted diaries, highlighting successes and providing advice for correcting deviations from diet prescriptions. Several strategies were used to maximize treatment fidelity. First, group workshops were scripted and written educational materials were developed to ensure delivery of wellâdefined nutrition messages for each diet group; otherwise, the format of the workshops and quality of the materials were completely parallel to maintain equal treatment intensity. Second, flowcharts provided structure for the private session and motivational telephone calls and were used to foster dietitian adherence to a participant centered counseling model, with adequate flexibility for addressing situations unique to each individual. Prompts for openâended questions were included in the flowcharts to enhance dialogue. The private session and telephone calls were digitally recorded, such that the study director and lead dietitian could monitor deviations from the protocol and provide feedback to dietitians as necessary. The duration of the private session and each telephone call also was monitored as an indicator of integrity with regard to treatment intensity. Third, weekly staff meetings provided an opportunity for continued discussion on intervention delivery, particularly strategies for assisting individual participants without compromising differentiation between diets. Fourth, dietitians were given detailed guidelines for providing written feedback on food diaries to avoid unintended overlap in dietary advice between groups. Participant adherence was evaluated based on attendance at group workshops and private sessions, completion of motivational telephone called and selfâreported dietary intake. In addition, data were obtained in regard to physical activity and participant satisfaction with program."Extent of intervention fidelity: For the lowâglycemic load group, glycemic index and carbohydrate intake decreased, producing a significant mean (SE) decrease in glycemic load (â19.8 [2.5] g/1000 kcal; P = 0.001). Examining the role of a highâprotein diet consumed over 12 weeks in slowing the progression heart failure and diabetes mellitusWhat (materials)? Participants were prescribed a hypocaloric diet incorporating a 500 to 800 kcal deficit per day into their individualised energy requirements. This was done through the provision of a standard structured energyârestricted meal plan. Participants were provided with a 'Participant Handbook' containing resources (such as lists of food items and serving sizes) and tools (such as weight charts, food checklists and threeâday food records). Participants were also provided with a pedometer.What (procedures)? The highâprotein diet consisted of 12 weeks following a diet with a macronutrient composition of 30% fat (~50 g/day), 40% carbohydrate (150 g/day) and 30% protein (~110 g/day). Participants were also encouraged to exercise regularly to promote weight loss, by engaging in 20 to 30 minutes of physical activity. Diet counselling sessions were provided.Who provided? A licenced dietitian provided the counselling sessions.How and where? Faceâtoâface counselling sessions were provided; the location of sessions was not reported. Sessions were on a oneâtoâone basis. Spouses, significant family members or friends were asked to participate in the sessions, if appropriate.When and how much? Counselling sessions were provided at visits at baseline, 2, 4, 8 and 12 weeks. The duration of sessions was between 45 to 60 minutes. The dietician provided detailed information on the meal plan and keeping daily food logs.Strategies to improve or maintain fidelity; tailoring and modification: Participants received a list of counselling appointments at baseline, and were reminded of sessions by phone call, text or email before each visit. The body weight, waist circumference and dietary intake of participants were reviewed at each visit; dietary adjustments were made if necessary. The dietitian reviewed completed dietary checklists and threeâday food records. The latter was done to clarify captured information, verify portions and obtain data that were incomplete. Pedometers were used by participants to monitor their own physical activity, changes in activity were also captured at each followâup visit. The authors also reported the following strategies to improve adherence: establishing a trusting relationship with participants; expressing appreciation for participation with cards and phone calls; providing easy access to investigators and research staff; providing culturally sensitive meal plans; paying for parking during visits; recognising potential barriers and helping to identify solutions; and enlisting family support. Early recognition of nonâadherence, identified through threeâday food records, prompted additonal education of participants and removal of obstacles.Extent of intervention fidelity: Threeâday food records reviewed at each visit were used to assess adherence. Examining the role of a standardâprotein diet consumed over 12 weeks in the progression of heart failure and diabetes mellitus, compared to a diet higher in proteinWhat (materials)? Participants were prescribed a hypocaloric diet incorporating a 500 to 800 kcal deficit per day into their individualised energy requirements. This was done through the provision of a standard structured energyârestricted meal plan. Participants were provided with a 'Participant Handbook' containing resources (such as lists of food items and serving sizes) and tools (such as weight charts, food checklists and threeâday food records). Participants were also provided with a pedometer.What (procedures)? The standardâprotein diet consisted of 12 weeks following a diet with a macronutrient composition of 30% fat (~50 g/day), 55% carbohydrate (~200 g/day) and 15% protein (~55 g/day). Participants were also encouraged to exercise regularly to promote weight loss, by engaging in 20 to 30 minutes of physical activity. Personalised nutritional counselling sessions were provided.Who provided? A licenced dietitian provided the counselling sessions.How and where? Faceâtoâface counselling sessions were provided; the location of sessions was not reported. Sessions were on a oneâtoâone basis. Spouses, significant family members or friends were asked to participate in the sessions, if appropriate.When and how much? Counselling sessions were provided at visits at baseline, 2, 4, 8 and 12 weeks. The duration of sessions was between 45 to 60 minutes. The dietician provided detailed information on the meal plan and keeping daily food logs.Strategies to improve or maintain fidelity; tailoring and modification: Participants received a list of counselling appointments at baseline, and were reminded of sessions by phone call, text or email before each visit. The body weight, waist circumference and dietary intake of participants were reviewed at each visit; dietary adjustments were made if necessary. The dietitian reviewed completed dietary checklists and threeâday food records. The latter was done to clarify captured information, verify portions and obtain data that were incomplete. Pedometers were used by participants to monitor their own physical activity, changes in activity were also captured at each followâup visit. The authors also reported the following strategies to improve adherence: establishing a trusting relationship with participants; expressing appreciation for participation with cards and phone calls; providing easy access to investigators and research staff; providing culturally sensitive meal plans; paying for parking during visits; recognising potential barriers and helping to identify solutions; and enlisting family support. Early recognition of nonâadherence, identified through threeâday food records, prompted additonal education of participants and removal of obstacles.Extent of intervention fidelity: Threeâday food records reviewed at each visit were used to assess adherence. The authors reported "high adherence" as a strength of the study.Concomitant interventions: Of control participants; 63% were treated with ACE inhibitors, 37% with angiotensin receptor blockers, 95% with betaâblockers, 72% with diuretics, 42% with digoxin, 26% with pain medication and 19% with antidepressants. Lowâcarbohydrate diets ad libitum diets may be at least as effective as traditional lowâfat, highâcarbohydrate diets for weight loss up to one year. The evidence to date is limited.What (materials)? Dr Atkins' New Diet Revolution (Atkins 2002).What (procedures)? Participants in this diet group aimed for the consumption of 20 g/d or less of carbohydrate for 'induction' (usually 2â3 months) and 50 g/d or less of carbohydrate for the subsequent 'ongoing weight loss' phase. Participants were assigned their diet book, attended regular classes covering the contents of the book and were administered unannounced dietary intake and energy expenditure questionnaires.Who provided? A registered dietitian led the classes and covered a portion of the book's contents per session so it would be complete at the end of the contact period. Unannounced dietary and exercise data were collected by persons trained and certified by the Nutrition Coordinating Centre.How and where? Class sessions were held faceâtoâface and in groups, location NR. Unannounced dietary and exercise data were collected by telephone.When and how much? Class sessions were one hour each and occurred every week for eight weeks. Unannounced dietary and exercise data were collected at baseline and at 2, 6 and 12 months. This entailed recall of three days (two weekdays and one weekend day, preferably nonâconsecutive) of dietary intake as well as seven days of physical activity.Strategies to improve or maintain fidelity; tailoring and modification: Strategies included email and telephone reminders for appointments, email or telephone contact from staff between the 2â and 6âmonth and between the 6â and 12âmonth data collection points, and incentive payments of $25, $50, and $75 for completing the 2â, 6â, and 12âmonth data collection, respectively. A âFood Amounts Bookletâ was used to assist participants with portion size estimation during dietary recalls. Unannounced dietary and exercise recalls, group sessions, measurement of body weight as part of study outcomesExtent of intervention fidelity: Dietary adherence scores calculated as the difference between reported and recommended daily carbohydrate intake (< = 20 g carbohydrate per day during the first two months; and <= 50 g carbohydrate per day for the subsequent 10 months), using the average of three nonâconsecutive 24âh dietary recalls at each time point. A lower score reflects better adherence. Adherence score, means (SD): at 2 months, 35.2 (32.7); at 6 months, 62.6 (64.7); at 12 months, 85.8 (70.5). In all 4 diet groups, 85% to 89% of participants attended at least 75% of their assigned classes (>= 6 of 8).
