full_text_sections.Title: Lowâcarbohydrate versus balancedâcarbohydrate diets for reducing weight and cardiovascular risk
full_text_sections.Abstract: Abstract Background Debates on effective and safe diets for managing obesity in adults are ongoing. Lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (also known as 'lowâcarb diets') continue to be widely promoted, marketed and commercialised as being more effective for weight loss, and healthier, than 'balanced'âcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets. Objectives To compare the effects of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets to weightâreducing diets with balanced ranges of carbohydrates, in relation to changes in weight and cardiovascular risk, in overweight and obese adults without and with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Search methods We searched MEDLINE (PubMed), Embase (Ovid), the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), Web of Science Core Collection (Clarivate Analytics), ClinicalTrials.gov and WHO International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (ICTRP) up to 25 June 2021, and screened reference lists of included trials and relevant systematic reviews.Â Language or publication restrictions were not applied. Selection criteria We included randomised controlled trials (RCTs) in adults (18 years+) who were overweight or living with obesity, without or with T2DM, and without or with cardiovascular conditions or risk factors. Trials had to compare lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets to balancedâcarbohydrate (45% to 65% of total energy (TE)) weightâreducing diets, have a weightâreducing phase of 2 weeks or longer and be explicitly implemented for the primary purpose of reducing weight, with or without advice to restrict energy intake.Â Data collection and analysis Two review authors independently screened titles and abstracts and fullâtext articles to determine eligibility; and independently extracted data, assessed risk of bias using RoB 2Â and assessed the certainty of the evidence using GRADE. We stratified analyses by participants without and with T2DM, and by diets with weightâreducing phases only and those with weightâreducing phases followed by weightâmaintenance phases. Primary outcomes were change in body weight (kg) and the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5%, assessed at shortâ (three months to < 12 months) and longâterm (â¥ 12 months) followâup. Main results We included 61 parallelâarm RCTs that randomised 6925 participants to either lowâcarbohydrate or balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets. All trialsÂ were conducted in highâincome countries except for oneÂ in China. Most participants (n = 5118 randomised) did not have T2DM. Mean baseline weight across trials was 95 kg (range 66 to 132 kg). Participants with T2DM were older (mean 57 years, range 50 to 65) than those without T2DM (mean 45 years, range 22 to 62). Most trials included men and women (42/61; 3/19 men only; 16/19 women only), and people without baseline cardiovascular conditions, risk factors or events (36/61). Mean baseline diastolic blood pressure (DBP) and lowâdensity lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol across trials were within normal ranges. The longest weightâreducing phase of diets was two years in participants without and with T2DM. Evidence from studies with weightâreducing phases followed by weightâmaintenance phases was limited. Most trials investigated lowâcarbohydrate diets (> 50 g to 150 g per day or < 45% of TE; n = 42), followed by very low (â¤ 50 g per day or < 10% of TE; n = 14), and then incremental increases from very low to low (n = 5). The most common diets compared were lowâcarbohydrate, balancedâfat (20 to 35% of TE) and highâprotein (> 20% of TE) treatment diets versus control diets balancedÂ for the three macronutrients (24/61). In most trials (45/61) the energy prescription or approach used to restrict energy intake was similar in both groups. We assessed the overall risk of bias of outcomes across trials as predominantly high, mostly from bias due to missing outcome data. Using GRADE, we assessed the certainty of evidence as moderate to very low across outcomes.Â Participants without and with T2DM lost weight when following weightâreducing phases of both diets at the short (range: 12.2 to 0.33 kg) and long term (range: 13.1 to 1.7 kg).Â In overweight and obese participants without T2DM: lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (weightâreducing phases only) probably result in little to no difference in change in body weight over three to 8.5 months (mean difference (MD) â1.07 kg, (95% confidence interval (CI) â1.55 to â0.59, I2 = 51%, 3286 participants, 37 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence) and over one to two years (MD â0.93 kg, 95% CI â1.81 to â0.04, I2 = 40%, 1805 participants, 14 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence); as well as change in DBP and LDL cholesterol over one to two years. The evidence is very uncertain about whether there is a difference in the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at one year (risk ratio (RR) 1.11, 95% CI 0.94 to 1.31, I2 = 17%, 137 participants, 2 RCTs,Â very lowâcertainty evidence).Â In overweight and obese participants with T2DM: lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (weightâreducing phases only) probably result in little to no difference in change in body weight over three to six months (MD â1.26 kg, 95% CI â2.44 to â0.09, I2Â = 47%, 1114 participants, 14 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence) and over one to two years (MD â0.33 kg, 95% CI â2.13 to 1.46, I2Â = 10%, 813 participants, 7 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence); as well in change in DBP, HbA1c and LDL cholesterol over 1 to 2 years. The evidence is very uncertain about whether there is a difference in the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at one to two years (RR 0.90, 95% CI 0.68 to 1.20, I2 =Â 0%, 106 participants, 2 RCTs,Â very lowâcertainty evidence).Â Evidence on participantâreported adverse effects was limited, and we could not draw any conclusions about these.Â Authors' conclusions There is probably little to no difference in weight reduction and changes in cardiovascular risk factors up to two years' followâup, when overweight and obese participants without and with T2DM are randomised to either lowâcarbohydrate or balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets.Â Plain language summary Lowâcarbohydrate diets or balancedâcarbohydrate diets: which works better for weight loss and heart disease risks?Â Key messages â¢ There is probably little to no difference in the weight lost by people following lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (also known as 'lowâcarb diets') compared to the weight lost by people following balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets, for up to two years. â¢ Similarly, there is probably little to no difference between the diets for changes in heart disease risks, like diastolic blood pressure, glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c, a measure of blood sugar levels over 2â3 months) and LDL cholesterol (âunhealthyâ cholesterol) up to two years. â¢ This was the case in people with and without type 2 diabetes. What are lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets? People spend lots of money on trying to lose weight using diets, products, foods and books, and continue to debate about which diets are effective and safe. So, examining the scientific evidence behind claims made is important. Lowâcarbohydrate diets are a broad category of weightâreducing diets that manipulate and restrict carbohydrates, protein and fat in diets. There are no consistent, widelyâaccepted definitions of these diets and different descriptions are used (such as, 'lowâcarbohydrate, highâproteinâ, 'lowâcarbohydrate, highâfat', or âvery lowâcarbohydrateâ). Lowâcarbohydrate diets are implemented in different ways, but they restrict grains, cereals and legumes, and other carbohydrateâcontaining foods; such as dairy, most fruit and certain vegetables. These foods are then typically replaced with foods higher in fat and protein; such as meats, eggs, cheese, butter, cream, oils. Some lowâcarbohydrate diets recommend eating as desired, while others recommend restricting the amount of energy eaten.Â Balancedâcarbohydrate diets contain more moderate amounts of carbohydrates, protein and fats, in line with current healthy eating advice from health authorities. When used for weight reduction, balanced diets recommend restricting the amount of energy eaten by guiding people to reduce their portion sizes and choose healthier foods (e.g. lean instead of fatty meat). Lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets are widely promoted, marketed and commercialised as being more effective for weight loss, and healthier, than 'balanced'âcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets. What did we want to find out? We wanted to find out if lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets were better for weight loss and heart disease risk factors than balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in adults who were overweight or living with obesity. We wanted to find this out for people with and without type 2 diabetes. What did we do?â¨We searched six electronic databases and trial registries for all trials* that compared lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in adults who were overweight or living with obesity. The trials had to last for at least three months. We compared and summarised the results of the trials and rated our confidence in the combined evidence, based on factors such as study methods and sizes.Â *A trial is a type of study in which participants are assigned randomly to two or more treatment groups. This is the best way to ensure similar groups of participants. What did we find? We found 61 trials involving 6925 people who were overweight or living with obesity. The biggest trial was in 419 people and the smallest was in 20 people. All except one of the trials were conducted in highâincome countries worldwide, and nearly half were undertaken in the USA (26). Most trials (36) were undertaken in people who did not have heart disease or risk factors. Most people (5118 people) did not have type 2 diabetes. The average starting weight of people across the trials was 95 kg. Most studies (37) lasted for six months or less; and the longest studies (6) lasted for two years. Main results Lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference in weight loss over the short term (trials lasting 3 to 8.5 months) and long term (trials lasting one to two years) compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets, in people with and without type 2 diabetes. In the short term, the average difference in weight loss was about 1 kg and in the long term, the average difference was less than 1 kg.Â People lost weight on both diets in some trials. The amount of weight lost on average varied greatly with both diets across the trials from less than 1 kg in some trials and up to about 12 kg in others in the short term and long term.Â Similarly, lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference in diastolic blood pressure, glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c) and LDL cholesterol (âunhealthyâ cholesterol) for up to two years.Â We could not draw any conclusions about unwanted effects reported by participants because very few trials reported these. What are the limitations of the evidence?Â We are moderately confident in the evidence. Our confidence was lowered mainly because of concerns about how some the trials were conducted, which included that many trials did not report all their results. Further research may change these results. How up to date is this evidence? The evidence is upâtoâdate to June 2021.
full_text_sections.RESULTS: Summary of findings Results Description of studies See: Characteristics of included studies; Characteristics of excluded studies; Characteristics of ongoing studies; Characteristics of studies awaiting classification. Results of the search Our electronic and manual searches yielded 5563 references, which includedÂ screening the reference lists of included trials and existing systematic reviews, with 2882 remaining after duplicate removal. We screened the titles and abstracts of these records and identified 475 as potentially eligibleÂ and obtained their full texts. We included 61 trials from 113Â references (Figure 1), of which three did not provide data that could be used in the quantitative syntheses (metaâanalyses) (Foster 2003;Â Pittas 2005;Â Racette 1995). Included studies Study locations and participants We included 61 parallelâarm individualÂ RCTs that randomised 6925 participants to either lowâcarbohydrate or balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets, and were published between 1978 and 2021. All trialsÂ were done in highâincome countries, except for one in China (Liu 2013); with 26 in the USA (Aude 2004;Â Bales 2017;Â Bazzano 2014;Â Brehm 2003;Â BrehmÂ 2005;Â Cornier 2005;Â Ebbeling 2007;Evangelista 2021Â Foraker 2014;Â Foster 2003;Â Foster 2010;Â Gardner 2007;Â Kitabchi 2013;Â Landers 2002;Â Lasker 2008;Â Layman 2005;Â Layman 2009;Â Pittas 2005;Â Racette 1995;Â Ruth 2013;Â Sacks 2009;Â Samaha 2003;Â Saslow 2017a;Â Stentz 2016;Â Volek 2009;Â Westman 2008); 14 in Australia (BenassiâEvans 2009;Â Farnsworth 2003;Â Griffin 2013;Â Jesudason 2013;Â Keogh 2007;Â Larsen 2011;Â Lim 2010;Â Parr 2016;Â Pedersen 2014;Â Tay 2008;Â Tay 2014;Â Watson 2016;Â Wycherley 2010;Â Wycherley 2012); five in Spain (CallejaâFernÃ¡ndez 2012;Â Goni 2018;Â JuanolaâFalgarona 2014;Â MarcoâBenedi 2019;Â MateoâGallego 2017); three in the UK (Dyson 2007;Â Hockaday 1978;Â Lean 1997), two in Sweden (Guldbrand 2012;Â Mellberg 2014), Norway (Klemsdal 2010;Â Veum 2017), Germany (Frisch 2009;Â Haufe 2013) andÂ Japan (Sato 2017;Â Yamada 2014);Â and one each in Canada (Josse 2011), Israel (Elhayany 2010), Singapore (Ooi 2021) and New Zealand (Krebs 2012). The large majority of trials were undertaken in outpatient clinics, medical centres andÂ research centres (50/61 trials), with the remaining 11 not reporting aÂ specific study setting. See theÂ Characteristics of included studiesÂ for additional details per study.Â Type 2 diabetes mellitus status of participants We stratified trials into those in participants without T2DM (comparisons 1 and 2)Â and those in participants with T2DM (comparisons 3 and 4), and also separated findings where people implemented only an active weightâreducing phase of the diets, from findings where people implemented a weightâreducing phase followed by a weightâmaintenance phase of the diets, as follows:Â comparison 1: trials in participants without T2DM including only weightâreducing phases of diets; comparison 2: trials in participants without T2DM including weightâreducing phases of diets followed by weightâmaintenance phases; comparison 3: trials in participants with T2DM including only weightâreducing phases of diets; comparison 4: trials in participants with T2DM including weightâreducing phases of diets followed by weightâmaintenance phases. WeÂ included 45/61 trialsÂ (n = 5118 randomised) in the two comparisons in participants without T2DM (comparisons 1 and 2). Of these, 36Â trials explicitly excluded participants with T2DM. For the remaining trials withÂ mixed participantsÂ or where this was unclearÂ (n = 9), the participants'Â baseline characteristicsÂ (e.g. HbA1c, fasting insulin, use of diabetes medication) were not indicative of diabetes (Bales 2017;Â Foraker 2014;Â Liu 2013;Â MarcoâBenedi 2019), more than 90% of the sampleÂ did not haveÂ T2DM (Aude 2004;Â Frisch 2009), participants with unstable metabolic disease were excluded (Jesudason 2013), or no relevant information was reported or could be obtained (Layman 2005;Â Layman 2009). We included 14/61 trialsÂ (n = 1604Â participants randomised) in the two comparisons in participants with T2DM (comparisons 3 and 4). Thirteen of theseÂ trials were conducted in participants withÂ diagnosed T2DM (Elhayany 2010;Â Evangelista 2021;Â Guldbrand 2012;Â Hockaday 1978;Â Krebs 2012;Â Larsen 2011;Â Pedersen 2014;Â Sato 2017;Â Tay 2014;Â Watson 2016;Â Westman 2008;Â Wycherley 2010;Â Yamada 2014). The other trial had mixed participants withÂ eligibility criteria being diabetes or prediabetes and more than 70% of participants were on diabetes medication at baselineÂ (Saslow 2017a). Two trials (n = 158 participants randomised) were conducted in participants without and with T2DMÂ and reported data separately for all (Dyson 2007), or some outcomes (Samaha 2003), which we included in theÂ appropriate comparisons, where possible. For the descriptions of participants, treatment and control diets that follow in this section, these two trialsÂ (Dyson 2007;Â Samaha 2003), are included with both strata of participants (without and with T2DM).Â Participants without T2DM: weightâreducing phase only (comparison 1) and weightâreducing phase followed by a weightâmaintenance phase (comparison 2) Sample size: The total numbers of participants randomised to the treatment and control diet arms ranged widely across these trials. The smallest trial randomised 20 participants (Racette 1995). Other small trials with 40 or fewer participants randomised includedÂ Cornier 2005;Â Dyson 2007;Â Kitabchi 2013Â andÂ Layman 2005. The largest trial in participants without T2DM wasÂ Sacks 2009Â (n = 405 randomised), with other trials including > 150 participants beingÂ Foster 2010;Â Frisch 2009;Â Haufe 2013;Â Jesudason 2013;Â andÂ Klemsdal 2010. Gender and age: In three of these trials, only men were eligibleÂ (BenassiâEvans 2009;Â Veum 2017;Â Wycherley 2012), in 16 only womenÂ (Bales 2017;Â Brehm 2003;Â BrehmÂ 2005;Â Cornier 2005;Â Foraker 2014;Â Gardner 2007;Â Griffin 2013;Â Jesudason 2013;Â Josse 2011;Â Kitabchi 2013;Â Layman 2005;Â Lean 1997;Â Liu 2013;Â MateoâGallego 2017;Â Mellberg 2014;Â Racette 1995),Â and in the rest,Â both men and women were eligible. Mean baseline age of participants across these trials was 45 years (range: 22 to 62Â years). Weight status: At baseline,Â mean body weight and BMI of participants without T2DM was 93.9 kg (range: 65 to 132 kg) and 33.6 kg/m2 (range:Â 30 to 43Â kg/m2), respectively. Cardiovascular health and risk factors: The majority of these trialsÂ included participants without cardiovascular conditions, risk factors or events at baseline (n = 30), one included participants with and without these (Aude 2004), and for theÂ remainingÂ trialsÂ this was unclear (Bales 2017;Â CallejaâFernÃ¡ndez 2012;Â Dyson 2007;Â Foraker 2014;Â JuanolaâFalgarona 2014;Â Keogh 2007;Â Kitabchi 2013;Â Lasker 2008;Â Layman 2005;Â MarcoâBenedi 2019;Â MateoâGallego 2017;Â Samaha 2003;Â Stentz 2016;Â Veum 2017;Â Volek 2009). Mean baseline LDL cholesterol concentration across these trials was 3.28 mmol/L (range: 2.58 to 4.47 mmol/L) and mean baseline DBP was 79 mmHg (range: 62 to 92 mmHg). Participants with T2DM: weightâreducing phase only (comparison 3) and weightâreducing phase followed by a weightâmaintenance phase (comparison 4) Sample size: The smallest trial in participants with T2DM randomised a total of 24 participants to the treatment and control diet arms (Yamada 2014), with other small trials (40 or fewer participants randomised) beingÂ Dyson 2007;Â Saslow 2017a;Â andÂ Wycherley 2010. The largest trial in participants with T2DM randomised 419 participants (Krebs 2012). Other trials including more than 130 participants wereÂ Elhayany 2010;Â Samaha 2003;Â andÂ Tay 2014. Gender and age: In all trials in participants with T2DM, both men and women were eligible for inclusion. Mean age of participants at baseline was 57 years (range: 50Â to 65Â years). Weight status: Mean baseline body weight of participants across these trials was 96.7 kg (range: 67 to 132 kg) and mean BMI was 34.5 kg/m2 (range 25Â to 42.9Â kg/m2). HbA1c: Mean baseline HbA1c of participants across these trials was 7.64% (range: 6.6% to 8.8%). Cardiovascular health: Six of these trials included participantsÂ without cardiovascular conditions, risk factors or events at baseline (Hockaday 1978;Â Krebs 2012;Â Larsen 2011;Â Tay 2014;Â Watson 2016;Â Wycherley 2010), one included participants with heart failure (Evangelista 2021), and, for the rest of the trials, this was unclear. Mean baseline LDL cholesterol across these trials was 2.63 mmol/L (range: 1.7 to 3.2 mmol/L) and mean baseline DBP was 78 mmHg (range: 70 to 84 mmHg). Treatment and control diets Trials in participants without T2DM: weightâreducing phase only (comparison 1) and weightâreducing phase followed by a weightâmaintenance phase (comparison 2) Duration: The duration of the weightâreducing phases of diets tested in these trials ranged from 12 weeks to two years, as follows: 10 trials for 12 weeks (Aude 2004;Â Dyson 2007;Â Farnsworth 2003;Â Keogh 2007;Â Landers 2002;Â Liu 2013;Â Racette 1995;Â Ruth 2013;Â Veum 2017;Â Volek 2009), eight trials for 16 weeks (BrehmÂ 2005;Â Cornier 2005;Â Goni 2018;Â Josse 2011;Â Lasker 2008;Â Layman 2005;Â Ooi 2021;Â Parr 2016), 12 trials for six months (Bales 2017;Â Brehm 2003;Â Foster 2003;Â Foster 2010;Â Haufe 2013;Â JuanolaâFalgarona 2014;Â Kitabchi 2013;Â Lean 1997;Â MarcoâBenedi 2019;Â MateoâGallego 2017;Â Pittas 2005;Â Stentz 2016), 12 trials for one year (Bazzano 2014;Â BenassiâEvans 2009;Â CallejaâFernÃ¡ndez 2012;Â Foraker 2014;Â Frisch 2009;Â Gardner 2007;Â Griffin 2013;Â Klemsdal 2010;Â Layman 2009;Â Samaha 2003;Â Tay 2008;Â Wycherley 2012), one trial for 15 months (Lim 2010), one trial for 18 months (Ebbeling 2007), and three trials for two years (Jesudason 2013;Â Mellberg 2014;Â Sacks 2009). We used only the data from the first six months in two trials with total durations of one year (Foster 2003) and two years (Foster 2010) since the treatment diets were ineligible from six months onwards due to the prescribed incremental carbohydrate increases. The results for only the active weightâreducing phases of the diets in participants without T2DM were reported in comparison 1. Five of these trials also implemented a weightâmaintenance phase following the weightâreducing phase for six weeks (Racette 1995), 40 weeks (Keogh 2007), 56 weeks (Farnsworth 2003), a variable time period with an average of 18 months (Haufe 2013) and 21 months (Dyson 2007), and these results were reported in comparison 2. Macronutrient prescription:Â Table 5Â contains the thresholds and rangesÂ used to characteriseÂ the macronutrient prescriptions of the treatment and control diets in this review. InÂ Table 6, we used the characterisations inÂ Table 5Â to summarise the macronutrient compositions of theÂ treatment and control diets tested in each trial in participants without T2DM.Â The extent of carbohydrate restriction in the treatment diets ranged fromÂ very lowÂ (â¤ 50 g per day or < 10% of total daily energy intake) (n = 11) toÂ lowÂ (> 50 g to 150 g per day or < 45% of total energy intake) (n = 31), with five trials examining the effects of treatment diets withÂ incremental increases in carbohydratesÂ from very low to low (Table 6). Implementation ofÂ these incremental increases varied widely across the five trials, with the prescribed time for following the very lowâcarbohydrate diets rangingÂ from one week toÂ three months. Different prescriptions for incremental increasesÂ in carbohydrate intake in the later phases included increases from 10% to 27% of total energy as carbohydrates, by 5 g/day/week,Â by 10 gÂ weekly, andÂ from 20 g to 50 g per day. As expected, the protein and fat proportions of treatment dietsÂ also varied concordantly.Â The control diets in theÂ majority of trials in participants without T2DM were balanced for carbohydrates, fat and protein (n = 38) (Table 6).Â The most common diets comparedÂ across the trials in participants without T2DM wereÂ lowâcarbohydrate, balancedâfat and highâprotein treatment diets compared to control diets balancedÂ for all three macronutrients (n = 19), followed by very lowâcarbohydrate treatment diets with unspecified fat and protein contents compared to control diets with balanced proportions ofÂ carbohydrates, fat and protein (n = 7)Â (Table 6). Total energy prescription: In most of these trials, the total energy prescription was similar, or the approach used to restrict energy intake was similar in treatment and control groups (n = 34). In nine other trials, the energy prescription was ad libitum in the treatment diets and restricted in the control diets (Aude 2004;Â Brehm 2003;Â BrehmÂ 2005;Â Foster 2003;Â Foster 2010;Â Gardner 2007;Â Landers 2002;Â Liu 2013;Â Samaha 2003). In the remaining trials, no energy prescription was reported, or unrestricted energy intake was prescribed for both treatment and control diets (Bazzano 2014;Â Ebbeling 2007;Â Mellberg 2014;Â Volek 2009). Trials in participants with T2DM: weightâreducing phase only (comparison 3) and weightâreducing phase followed by a weightâmaintenance phase (comparison 4) Duration: The duration of the weightâreducing phases of diets tested in these trials ranged from 12 weeks to two years, as follows: four trials for 12 weeks (Dyson 2007;Â Evangelista 2021;Â Larsen 2011;Â Watson 2016), one trial for 16 weeks (Wycherley 2010), three trials for six months (Sato 2017;Â Westman 2008;Â Yamada 2014), five trials for one year (Elhayany 2010;Â Hockaday 1978;Â Pedersen 2014;Â Samaha 2003;Â Saslow 2017a), and three trials for two years (Guldbrand 2012;Â Krebs 2012;Â Tay 2014). The results for only the active weightâreducing phases of diets in participants with T2DM were reported in comparison 3. Four of these trials also implemented a weightâmaintenance phase following their weightâreducing phase for 12 weeks (Watson 2016), nine months (Larsen 2011), 12 months (Sato 2017), and 21 months (Dyson 2007), and we reported these results in comparison 4. Macronutrient prescriptions:Â Table 7Â summarisesÂ the macronutrient prescriptions of theÂ treatment and control diets tested in each trial in participants with T2DM using the characterisations inÂ Table 5.Â The extent of carbohydrate restriction in the treatment diets ranged fromÂ very low (â¤ 50 g per day) (n = 5) toÂ lowÂ (> 50 g to 150 g per day or < 45% of total energy intake) (n = 11). No trials in participants with T2DM tested treatment diets with incremental increases in carbohydrates. Protein and fat proportions of treatment diets varied concordantly or were not reported.Â The control diets in theÂ majority of trials in participants with T2DM were balanced for carbohydrates, fat and protein (n = 13) (Table 7).Â As seen in the trials in participants without T2DM, the most common treatment diets comparedÂ across the trials in participants with T2DM wereÂ 'low'âcarbohydrate, balancedâfat and highâprotein treatment diets compared to control diets balancedÂ for all three macronutrients (n = 5). This was followed by 'very low'âcarbohydrate treatment diets with unspecified fat and protein contents compared to control diets with balancedâcarbohydrates and unspecified fat and protein contents (n = 2)Â (Table 7). Total energy prescription: In most of these trials, the total energy prescription was similar, or the approach used to restrict energy intake was similar in treatment and control groups (n = 11). In the remaining trials, the energy prescription was ad libitum in the treatment diets and restricted in the control diets (Samaha 2003;Â Saslow 2017a;Â Sato 2017;Â Westman 2008;Â Yamada 2014). TheÂ Characteristics of included studiesÂ table contains key items from the template for intervention description and replication (TIDieR) checklist and guide (Hoffman 2014), including materials and procedures used to implement the diets; and who, how, where, and when the diets were implemented in each trial. Funding of included trials About 60% (n = 28) of the trials including participants without T2DM reported being funded only by nonâcommercial funders, including government and public research institutes, while 36% (n = 17) reported some or all funding by food/diet industry and related private companies, such as food and nutrition product manufacturers, organisations representing the interests of food producers (e.g. Pork Council, Dairy Farmers Association) and diet book and diet product organisations (Bales 2017;Â BenassiâEvans 2009;Â Dyson 2007;Â Farnsworth 2003;Â Frisch 2009;Â Griffin 2013;Â Josse 2011;Â Lasker 2008;Â Layman 2005;Â Layman 2009;Â Lean 1997;Â Liu 2013;Â Parr 2016;Â Racette 1995;Â Ruth 2013;Â Volek 2009;Â Wycherley 2012). Sources of funding were not reported by two trials in participants without T2DM (Aude 2004;Â Landers 2002). About a third of trials including participants with T2DM (38%; n = 6) were funded solely by nonâcommercial funders, with seven trials (41%) reporting some or all funding by food/diet industry and related private companies (Dyson 2007;Â Hockaday 1978;Â Larsen 2011;Â Sato 2017;Â Watson 2016;Â Westman 2008;Â Wycherley 2010), and three trials not reporting funding source (Elhayany 2010;Â Pedersen 2014;Â Yamada 2014). Excluded studies We contacted 64 corresponding authorsÂ forÂ further information to assist with study inclusion.Â We excludedÂ 323 fullâtext articles with reasons, as follows. Linked to an included trial but no data used:Â 82 No defined carbohydrate prescription used by study authors for the intervention and/or control diets: 28 Duplicate: 27 Ineligible study design: 26 Not lowâcarbohydrate intervention diet: 27 Carbohydrate contents of diets not adequately defined and could not be obtained from study authors: 22 Focus of diets are on specific foods/replacements, food groups/components: 20 Both diets are not low in carbohydrates: 18 Ineligible duration: 17 Ineligible participants: 16 Diets not for intended for weight loss: 9 Both diets are low in carbohydrates: 7 Diets differ by group in other ways that may influence outcomes: 7 Control diet not balanced in carbohydrates: 4 Coâinterventions differ by group: 4 Data from the weightâreducing phase of diets not available: 2 Record of an additional study using participants from an included trial: 4 Control diet not for weight loss: 1 Other: 2 TheÂ Characteristics of excluded studiesÂ table contains the key studies excluded with reasons. The remaining referencesÂ whereÂ we could not reach the authors or information provided was not sufficient to make a clear judgement (n = 33), were includedÂ asÂ Studies awaiting classification. The nine ongoing studies are detailed inÂ Characteristics of ongoing studies. Risk of bias in included studies Risk of bias assessmentsÂ for each outcome included in the summary of findings tables, along with all domain judgements, are included in the forest plots.Â Figure 2Â provides our judgements about each risk of bias item presented as percentages across all included trials for bias arising from the randomisation process, and across all outcomes in the summary of findings tables for all other items using RoB 2. Additional information, such as support for judgements, is locatedÂ in theÂ risk of biasÂ section (located after theÂ Characteristics of ongoing studies).Â For most trials in participants without T2DM, the risk of bias arising from the randomisation process was judged as having 'some concerns' (n = 25), 10 trials were judged as low risk (Bales 2017;Â Dyson 2007;Â Ebbeling 2007;Â Gardner 2007;Â Griffin 2013;Â Haufe 2013;Â Jesudason 2013;Â Liu 2013;Â MarcoâBenedi 2019;Â Sacks 2009), and four trials as high risk for this domain (Keogh 2007;Â Parr 2016;Â Tay 2008;Â Wycherley 2012). The overall risk of bias of outcomes across trials in participants without T2DM was similar and predominantly high. High overall risk of bias judgements were mostly as a result of bias due to missing outcome data, with high proportions of missing outcome data in many trials and this not being adequately handled by recommended statistical approaches. Bias due to deviations from intended interventions also contributed to high overall risk of bias. Problems with the measurement of outcomes did not contribute to high overall risk as most outcomes were not subjective or observerâreported; the exception was constipation, which was participantâreported and judged as high risk for most of the trials. None of the trials for any outcome in participants without T2DM reported prespecified analysis intentions in sufficient detail to enable assessment of selection of the reported result. Three trials did not contribute any numeric data to metaâanalyses and risk of bias for these trials was not assessed, in line with guidance on implementing RoB 2 (Foster 2003;Â Pittas 2005;Â Racette 1995).Â Five trials did not report any outcomes included in the summary of findings tables, and we did not assess risk of bias of these (JuanolaâFalgarona 2014;Â Kitabchi 2013;Â Ruth 2013;Â Samaha 2003;Â Stentz 2016).Â Bias arising from the randomisation process was judged as low risk for approximately half of the trials in participants with T2DM (n = 8) (Dyson 2007;Â Evangelista 2021;Â Krebs 2012;Â Larsen 2011;Â Pedersen 2014;Â Saslow 2017a;Â Sato 2017;Â Watson 2016), with the remaining trials judged as having 'some concerns' (Elhayany 2010;Â Guldbrand 2012;Â Samaha 2003;Â Tay 2014;Â Westman 2008;Â Wycherley 2010;Â Yamada 2014). Across trials in participants with T2DM, the overall risk of bias of outcomes was similar and mostly high. As in the trials in participants without T2DM, the high overall risk of bias judgements were largely driven by bias due to missing outcome data, with high proportions of missing data not being adequately handled, and to a lesser extent by bias due to deviations from intended interventions. None of the trials in participants with T2DM reported prespecified analysis intentions in sufficient detail to enable us to assess the selection of the reported result. We did not assess risk of bias for one older study as it did not contribute usable data for an outcome included in the summary of findings tables (Hockaday 1978).Â Effects of interventions See: Table 1; Table 2; Table 3; Table 4 See:Â Table 1;Â Table 2;Â Table 3;Â Table 4. We analysed results from trials in overweight and obese participants without T2DM separately from those in participants with T2DM. We also separated analyses for weightâreducing phases of diets, and for weightâreducing phases followed by weightâmaintenance phases. We report here the effects on the prespecified outcomes according to the four comparisons resulting from these stratifications.Â We assessed the followâup periods for the various outcomes as short term (three to < 12 months) or long term (â¥ 12 months). The exact authorâreported followâup periods per outcome per trial appear as footnotes in each forest plot (i.e. using weeks, months or years). To summarise the followâup period applicable per outcome, we also reported the specific followâup range across all the trials that reported on that outcome. None of the included trials reported on the following outcomes for any of the four comparisons: allâcause mortality, cardiovascular mortality, nonâfatal myocardial infarction, nonâfatal stroke and diagnosis of T2DM. Trials without usable data for outcomes in the summary of findings tables are summarised inÂ Table 8Â for comparisons 1 and 2 and inÂ Table 9Â for comparisons 3 and 4. Â Â The assumed risk in comparison groups was expressed as the range of change values reported in the balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diet groups across the studies that reported results for a given outcome. If only end values were reported for a given outcome, a mean change value was calculated by using the mean baseline value and subtracting it from the reported mean end value.Â Comparison 1. Lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets versus balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (weightâreducing phase only) Table 1Â presents the effects of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (weightâreducing phase only) in overweight and obese participants without T2DM on shortâterm (three to <12 months) and longâterm (â¥ 12 months) changes in body weight, as well as on the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% over the long term, longâterm change in DBP and LDL cholesterol, and shortâterm constipation. Key details about studies in this comparison, including characteristics of the intervention, population, outcomes and method of synthesis, are included in the Overview of Synthesis and Included Studies (OSIS) table (Table 10). Primary outcomes Change in body weight (kg) at three to < 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference in change in body weight over three to 8.5 months compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (moderateâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias).Â Average weight reductions from baseline over the short term ranged from 12.18 kg to 4.45 kg with lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets and from 11.34 kg to 2.3 kg with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in the 37 trials that reported this outcome. The metaâanalysis showed little to no difference in weight reduction on average between lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups (MD â1.07 kg, (95% confidence interval (CI) â1.55 to â0.59, I2 = 51%, 3286 participants, 37 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 1.1) over three to 8.5 months. This lack of a difference in effect was confirmed by sensitivity analyses, including only trials with 'some concerns' of bias overall (Analysis 1.6; no trials at overall low risk of bias), those at low risk of attrition bias (Analysis 1.7) and those without reported diet/food industry funding (Analysis 1.8).Â Subgrouping by similarity of energy prescription (Analysis 1.2), extent of carbohydrate restriction (Analysis 1.3), diagnosed cardiovascular event or disease at baseline (Analysis 1.4) or gender (Analysis 1.5) did not suggest important clinical differences in average effects between subgroups, with mean differences in weight reduction in overweight and obese participants at three to < 12 months ranging between 0.25 kg and 2.71 kg across the various subgroups. Subgrouping by similarity of energy prescription and extent of carbohydrate restriction explained some heterogeneity. Heterogeneity was reduced (I2 = 0%) in the subgroup including only trials with similar energy prescriptions/approaches to energy restriction in both diets, and in the subgroup including only trials investigating lowâcarbohydrate diets (> 50 g to 150 g per day or < 45% of total energy intake). We did not downgrade for inconsistency. The subgroup including only trials with no energy prescriptions or unrestricted energy prescriptions in both diets had small total numbers of participants (n < 400). This was also the case for the subgroup of trials only including men.Â Nine trials reported this outcome in an unusable format (e.g. in figures or as percentage change in weight from baseline) and usable data were not provided when authors were contacted (Table 8). The funnel plot (Figure 3) shows most trials had similar standard errors of intervention effect estimates limiting the ability to assess asymmetry. The mean difference in fixedâeffect analysis, which gives less weight to small studies (â0.91 kg, 95% CI â1.21 to â0.62), is similar to the mean difference in randomâeffects metaâanalysis (â1.07 kg, 95% CI â1.55 to â0.59,Â Analysis 1.1), which gives more weight to smaller studies, suggesting that any smallâstudy effects have little effect on the intervention effect estimate. Thirteen of the 37 trials had followâup at three months from baseline, nine at four months, 13 at six months, one at 26 weeks (about 6.5 months), and one trial at 34 weeks (about 8.5 months) Change in body weight (kg) at â¥ 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference to change in body weight over one to two years compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (moderateâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias). Longâterm average weight reductions in the 14 trials that reported this outcome ranged from 13.1 kg to 2.46 kg in lowâcarbohydrate diet groups and from 11.6 kg to 1.7 kg in balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in weight reduction between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one to two years (MD â0.93 kg, 95% CI â1.81 to â0.04, I2 = 40%, 1805 participants, 14 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 1.9). Sensitivity analyses including only trials at low risk of attrition bias (Analysis 1.10) and trials without diet/food industry funding confirmed this lack of a difference in effect (Analysis 1.11). Other planned sensitivity analyses included fewer than two studies and thus were not performed. Two trials reported this outcome in an unusable format (e.g. in figures or as percentage change in weight from baseline) and usable data were not provided when authors were contacted (Table 8). The funnel plot (Figure 4) suggests that smaller studies may be missing. The mean difference in fixedâeffect analysis, which gave less weight to small studies (â0.81 kg, 95% CI â1.43 to â0.19), was similar to the mean difference in the randomâeffects metaâanalysis (â0.93 kg, 95% CI â1.81 to â0.04,Â Analysis 1.9), which gave more weight to smaller studies, suggesting that any smallâstudy effects had little effect on the intervention effect estimate. Ten of the 14 trials had followâup at one year, one at 15 months, one at 74 weeks (about 18.5 months), with the two longest trials having followâup at two years. Number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at three to < 12 months The number of participants achieving at least 5% weight loss over the short term in the three trials reporting this outcome ranged from 14 to 41 with lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets and from eight to 35 with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets. The metaâanalysis of the risk ratio (RR) of the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at three to six months was 1.30 (95% CI 1.00 to 1.68, I2 = 47%, 161 participants, 3 RCTs,Â Analysis 1.12) when comparing lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups. Two of the three trials that reported this outcome had followâup at three months and the other at six months. Number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at â¥ 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that the evidence is very uncertain about whether there is a difference in the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at one year, when comparing lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (very lowâcertainty evidence; downgraded once for risk of bias and twice for imprecision). Two studies reported on this outcome at one year (RR 1.11, 95% CI 0.94 to 1.31; IÂ² = 17%; 137 participants, 2 RCTs,Â very lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 1.13), with the number of participants achieving at least 5% weight loss ranging from 28 to 30 in the lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing group and from 27 to 29 in the balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing group. Another included trial also measured this outcome at two years but it was not reported in a usable format (Table 8).Â Secondary outcomes For comparison 1, no trials reported on the number of participants per group with reduction in BMI (kg/m2) of at least 5% at â¥ 12 months. Change in BMI (kg/m2) at three to < 12 months Twentyâone trials (n = 1517 participants) reported on shortâterm BMI change for comparison 1, with five of the 20 trials having followâup at three months, five at four months and 11 trials at six months. Change in DBP (mmHg) at â¥ 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference to change in DBP compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets over one to two years in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (moderateâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias). Seven of the 11 trials had followâup at one year, one at 15 months, one at 18 months and the other two trials at two years. Change in SBP (mmHg) at â¥ 12 months Average change in SBP from baseline in the 11 trials reporting this outcome ranged from reductions of 13.8 mmHg to 0.2 mmHg in lowâcarbohydrate diet groups and from a reduction of 14.6 mmHg to an increase of 1.7 mmHg in balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups over one to two years of followâup. Participantâreported adverse effects Participantâreported adverse effects were scantily reported by six included trials for comparison 1, with all outcomes except shortâterm constipation being reported only by single trials, and one of the trials reporting on most of these outcomes (Bazzano 2014). All 19 dichotomous outcomes reported very few events, had small total sample sizes and had wide 95% CIs. The four continuous outcomes all had small total samples sizes, mean differences close to 0 and wide 95% CIs. Gastrointestinal GRADE assessment suggests that the evidence is very uncertain about whether there is a difference in the number of participants per group with constipation at three to six months when comparing lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (very lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and twice for imprecision).Â The metaâanalysis of the risk ratio of the number of participants per group reporting constipation at three to six months was 1.06 (95% CI 0.81 to 1.38, I2 = 0%, 564 participants, 4 RCTs,Â very lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 1.24) when comparing the two diet groups.Â One trial reported constipation at one year (RR 0.63, 95% CI 0.32 to 1.25, 148 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 1.25). Two trials reported on events of diarrhoea finding no difference over the shorter term (at three months and at six months) (RR 0.98, 95% CI 0.33 to 2.93, 244 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 1.26) or at one year (RR 0.32, 95% CIÂ 0.03 to 3.05, 148 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 1.27). Comparison 2. Lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets versus balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (weightâreducing phase followed by weightâmaintenance phase) Table 2Â presents the effects of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (weightâreducing phase followed by weightâmaintenance phase) in overweight and obese participants without T2DM on longâterm (â¥ 12 months) changes in body weight, DBP and LDL cholesterol. Key details about studies in this comparison, including characteristics of the intervention, population, outcomes and method of synthesis are detailed in the OSIS table (Table 10). Primary outcomes The only primary outcome reported by the included trials for comparison 2 was change in body weight at â¥ 12 months. Change in body weight (kg) at â¥ 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase may result in little to no difference in change in body weight over one to two years compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and once for imprecision). Over the long term, average weight change from baseline ranged from a reduction of 5.4 kg to an increase of 0.86 kg with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from reductions of 5.5 kg to 1.5 kg with balancedâcarbohydrate diets across the three trials that reported this outcome. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in weight reduction between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one to two years (MD â0.30 kg, 95% CI â2.77 to 2.16, I2 = 0%, 73 participants, 3 RCTs,Â lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 2.1). One of the trials had a weightâreducing phase of 12 weeks followed by a weightâmaintenance phase of 40 weeks, measuring change in weight at one year. The other two trials measured change in weight at two years, with one trial testing a threeâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a 21âmonth maintenance phase, and the other trial testing a 6âmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a maintenanceâphase that averaged 18 months in duration. This lack of a difference in effect was confirmed by a sensitivity analysis including only the two trials without reported diet/food industry funding (MD â0.80 kg, 95% CI â3.48 to 1.88, I2 = 0%, 63 participants, 2 RCTs, analysis not shown).Â Secondary outcomes The only secondary outcomes reported by the included trials for comparison 2 were changes in DBP, SBP, LDL and HDL cholesterol, total cholesterol and triglycerides. Â Changes in DBP and SBP (mmHg) at â¥ 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that the evidence is very uncertain about the effect of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase on change in DBP at one year in overweight and obese participants without T2DM (very lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and twice for imprecision). One very small trial compared these diets using a weightâreducing phase of 12 weeks followed by a maintenance phase of 40 weeks, and reported on changes in DBP (MD â6.0 mmHg, 95% CI â17.55 to 5.55, 13 participants, 1 RCT,Â very lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 2.2) and SBPÂ (MD â15.0 mmHg, 95% CI â32.36 to 2.36, 13 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 2.3) at one year. For SBP, the study reported an average decrease from baseline of 2 mmHg in the lowâcarbohydrate group and an increase of 2 mmHg in the balancedâcarbohydrate group. One trial used a weightâreducing phase of 12 weeks followed by a maintenance phase of 40 weeks, and the other trial used a weightâreducing phase of six months followed by a maintenance phase of 18 months with changes reported at one and two years, respectively for LDL cholesterol (MD â0.08 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.44 to 0.28, I2 = 0%, 56 participants, 2 RCTs, very lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 2.4), HDL cholesterol (MD â0.05 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.37 to 0.28, I2 = 5%, 56 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 2.5), total cholesterol (MD â0.08 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.43 to 0.27, I2 = 0%, 56 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 2.6) and triglycerides (MD â0.08 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.34 to 0.17, I2 = 0%, 56 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 2.7).Â Average LDL cholesterol reductions from baseline ranged from 0.79 mmol/L to 0.2 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from 1.15 mmol/L to 0.14 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. Key details about studies in this comparison, including characteristics of the intervention, population, outcomes and method of synthesis can be found in the OSIS table (Table 10). Primary outcomes Change in body weight (kg) at three to < 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference in change in body weight over three to six months compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (moderateâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias). Average weight reductions from baseline over three to six months ranged from 12 kg to 2.41 kg with lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets and from 11.5 kg to 0.33 kg with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in the 14 trials reporting this outcome. The metaâanalysis showed little to no difference in weight reduction on average between lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups over three to six months (MD â1.26 kg, 95% CI â2.44 to â0.09, I2 = 47%, 1114 participants, 14 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 3.1). This lack of a difference in effect was also seen with sensitivity analyses including only trials with 'some concerns' of bias overall (Analysis 3.2, no trials at overall low risk of bias), at low risk of attrition bias (Analysis 3.3) and without reported diet/food industry funding (Analysis 3.4).Â One included trial also measured change in body weight at three to < 12 months but reported it in an unusable format (Table 9). The funnel plot (Figure 5) suggests that smaller studies may be missing. The mean difference in fixedâeffect analysis, which gives less weight to small studies (â0.92 kg, 95% CI â1.65 to â0.19), is similar to the mean difference in randomâeffects metaâanalysis (â1.26 kg, 95% CI â2.44 to â0.09,Â Analysis 3.1), which gives more weight to smaller studies, suggesting that any smallâstudy effects have little effect on the intervention effect estimate. Four of the 14 trials had followâup at three months from baseline, one trial at four months and nine at six months.Â Change in body weight (kg) at â¥ 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference in change in body weight over one to two years compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (moderateâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias). Average weight reductions from baseline over one to two years in the seven trials reporting this outcome ranged from 8.9 kg to 2 kg with lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets and from 7.4 kg to 1.7 kg with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets. The metaâanalysis showed little to no difference in weight reduction on average between lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups over one to two years (MD â0.33 kg, 95% CI â2.13 to 1.46, I2 = 10%, 813 participants, 7 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 3.5). This lack of a difference in effect was also seen with the sensitivity analysis including only trialsÂ without diet/food industry funding (Analysis 3.6). Other planned sensitivity analyses included only one or two studies and thus were not performed.Â Of the seven trials, four had followâup at one year and three had followâup at two years. The oldest included trial also measured change in body weight at â¥ 12 months but reported it in an unusable format (Table 9).Â Number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at three to < 12 months A single small study reported on this outcome at three months and the risk ratio was 1.01 (95% CI 0.77 to 1.33, 45 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 3.7) with 19 participants in the lowâcarbohydrate group and 18 participants in the balancedâcarbohydrate group achieving at least 5% weight loss from baseline. Number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at â¥ 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that the evidence is very uncertain about whether there is a difference in the number of participants per group with weight loss of at least 5% at one to two years, when comparing lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (very lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias, once for indirectness and twice for imprecision). Two studies reported on this outcome at one and two years (RR 0.90, 95% CI 0.68 to 1.20; IÂ² = 0; 106 participants, 2 RCTs,Â very lowâcertainty evidence,Â ) with the number of participants achieving at least 5% weight loss from baseline ranging from 10 to 22 in the lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing group and 14 to 20 in the balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing group.Â Secondary outcomes For comparison 3, no studies reported on the number of participants per group with reduction in BMI (kg/m2) of at least 5%. Change in BMI (kg/m2) at three to < 12 months Eleven trials (n = 515 participants) reported on shortâterm BMI change. Across these trials, average reductions in BMI from baseline ranged from 4 kg/m2 to 0.87 kg/m2 with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from 4 kg/m2 to 0.1 kg/m2 with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. We did not pool these results into an overall effect estimate due to substantial heterogeneity (IÂ² = 57%, TauÂ² = 0.56; ChiÂ² = 23.11, df = 10 (P = 0.01)) but rather presented the individual effect sizes between the two types of diet per study (Analysis 3.9). Three of the 10 trials had followâup at three months, one at four months and seven at six months. Change in BMI (kg/m2) at â¥ 12 months Average reductions in BMI from baseline over the long term in the four trials reporting this outcome ranged from 3.3 kg/m2 to 0.8 kg/m2 with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from 2.6 kg/m2 to 0.9 kg/m2 with balancedâcarbohydrate diets.Â When lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets were compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets, the difference in BMI change on average at one to two years was â0.29 kg/m2 (95% CI â1.06 to 0.48, I2 = 13%, 329 participants, 4 RCTs,Â Analysis 3.10). Two trials had followâup at one year and the remaining two at two years. Change in DBP (mmHg) at â¥ 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference to change in DBP compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets over one to two years in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (moderateâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias). Over one to two years, average changes from baseline in DBP ranged from a reduction of 5 mmHg to an increase 3 mmHg in lowâcarbohydrate diet groups and from a reduction of 6 mmHg to an increase of 4.3 mmHg in balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups across the six trials reporting on this outcome. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in change in DBP between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one to two years (MD â0.28 mmHg 95% CI â1.84 to 1.28, I2 = 0%, 631 participants, 6 RCTs, moderateâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 3.11). Three of the six trials had followâup at one year and the other three at two years. Change in SBP (mmHg) at â¥ 12 months Average change in SBP from baseline in the six trials reporting this outcome ranged from a reduction of 9 mmHg to an increase of 3.2 mmHg with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from a reduction of 11 mmHg to an increase of 2.4 mmHg with balancedâcarbohydrate diets over one to two years of followâup. The mean difference in change in SBP at one to two years was 0.32 mmHg (95% CI â2.30 to 2.93, I2 = 0%, 629 participants, 6 RCTs,Â Analysis 3.12). Three of the six trials had followâup at one year and the other three at two years. Change in HbA1c (%) at 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference to change in HbA1c compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets over one to two years in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (moderateâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias). Average change in HbA1c from baseline over one to two years ranged from a reduction of 2% to an increase of 0.1% with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from a reduction of 1.8% to an increase of 0.2% with balancedâcarbohydrate diets across the six trials that reported this outcome. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in change in HbA1c between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one to two years (MD â0.14% 95% CI â0.38 to 0.10, I2 = 31%, 668 participants, 6 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 3.13). Four of the six trials had followâup at one year and the other two had followâup at two years. One included trial also measured change in HbA1c in diabetic participants only at one year but reported it in an unusable format (Table 9). Change in LDL cholesterol (mmol/L) at â¥ 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets probably result in little to no difference in change in LDLâcholesterol over one to two years compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (moderateâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias). Average change from baseline over one to two years across the seven trials reporting on change in LDL cholesterol ranged from a reduction of 0.61 mmol/L to an increase of 0.2 mmol/L in lowâcarbohydrate diet groups and from a reduction of 0.55 mmol/L to an increase of 0.1 mmol/L in balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in change in LDL cholesterol between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one to two years (MD 0.12 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.03 to 0.26, I2 = 34%, 753 participants, 7 RCTs,Â moderateâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 3.14). Four of the seven trials had followâup at one year; the other three had followâup at two years. Change in HDL cholesterol (mmol/L) at â¥ 12 months Over one to two years, average change from baseline across the seven trials reporting on change in HDL cholesterol ranged from a reduction of 0.03 mmol/L to an increase of 0.23 mmol/L in lowâcarbohydrate diet groups and from a reduction of 0.13 mmol/L to an increase of 0.11 mmol/L in balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups. We did not pool these results into an overall effect estimate due to substantial heterogeneity (IÂ² = 67%, TauÂ² = 0.01; ChiÂ² = 18.34, df = 6 (P = 0.005)) but rather presented the individual effect sizes between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets per study (Analysis 3.15). Four of the seven trials had followâup at one year and the other three had followâup at two years. Change in nonâHDL cholesterol (mmol/L) at â¥ 12 months Two studies reported on this outcome at one and two years and the mean difference in nonâHDL cholesterol was 0.09 mmol/L (95% CI â0.39 to 0.58, I2 = 0%, 159 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 3.16) with average increases in nonâHDL ranging from 0.13 mmol/L to 0.2 mmol/L in the lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing group and from 0.1 mmol/L to 0.17 mmol/L in the balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing group.Â Â Change in total cholesterol (mmol/L) at â¥ 12 months Average change from baseline over one to two years across the seven trials reporting on change in total cholesterol ranged from a reduction of 0.88 mmol/L to an increase of 0.2 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from reductions of 0.96 mmol/L to 0.1 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. The mean difference in change in total cholesterol at one to two years was 0.21 mmol/L (95% CI 0.06 to 0.37, I2 = 25%, 838 participants, 7 RCTs,Â Analysis 3.17). Four of the seven trials had followâup at one year and the other three trials at two years. Change in triglycerides (mmol/L) at â¥ 12 months Over one to two years, average change in triglycerides from baseline triglycerides ranged from reductions of 1.52 mmol/L to 0.1 mmol/L in lowâcarbohydrate diet groups and from a reduction of 1.46 mmol/L to an increase of 0.16 mmol/L in balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups across the seven trials reporting on this outcome. We did not pool these results into an overall effect estimate due to substantial heterogeneity (IÂ² = 75%, TauÂ² = 0.07; ChiÂ² = 23.97, df = 6 (P = 0.0005) but rather presented the individual effect sizes between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets per study (Analysis 3.18). Five of the seven trials had followâup at one year and the remaining two trials at two years. Another trial reported change in triglycerides at two years as medians and interquartile ranges as the data were not normally distributed (Krebs 2012).Â Participantâreported adverse effects Participantâreported adverse effects were scantily reported by three included trials for comparison 3, with all outcomes except shortâterm constipation being reported only by single trials. All adverse effect outcomes reported in these trials had very few events or mean differences close to 0 and small total sample sizes.Â Gastrointestinal GRADE assessment suggests that the evidence is very uncertain about whether there is a difference in the number of participants per group with constipation at three to six months when comparing lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (very lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and twice for imprecision).Â The metaâanalysis of the risk ratio of the number of participants per group reporting constipation at six months was 1.37 (95% CI 0.86 to 2.18, I2 = 0%, 177 participants, 2 RCTs,Â very lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 3.19) when comparing lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diet groups. One included trial also measured constipation at three months but reported data in an unusable format (Table 9). One trial reported constipation at one year (RR 2.71, 95% CI 0.11 to 64.65, 78 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 3.20). One trial reported on events of diarrhoea at six months (RR 1.07, 95% CI 0.62 to 1.84, 84 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 3.21). Another trial (using an adaption of the Health Symptom Checklist) (Saslow 2017a) reported "no statistically significant changes" for diarrhoea at three months (data were not reported or provided when authors were contacted), and also reported heartburn symptoms at three months (MD â0.30, 95% CIÂ â0.66 to 0.06, 33 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 3.22). Appetite One trial reported on appetite change from baseline at three months using the threeâfactor eating questionnaire (MD â0.70, 95% CIÂ â3.03 to 1.63, 33 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 3.23). Headaches One trial reported on events of headaches at six months (RR 1.15, 95% CI 0.75 to 1.78, 84 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 3.24). Another trial reported no statistical difference between participants in the lowâcarbohydrate diet group and the balancedâdiet group for headaches at three months (used adaptation of the Health Symptom Checklist), but data were not reported or provided when authors were contacted (Saslow 2017a). Psychosocial problems (mood disturbances) Â At three months followâup, one trial reported depressive symptoms according to the 20âitem Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CESâD) (MD â0.20, 95% CI â9.20 to 8.80, 33 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 3.25). Comparison 4. Lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets versus balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (weightâreducing phase followed by weightâmaintenance phase) Table 4Â presents the effects of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets (weightâreducing phase followed by weightâmaintenance phase) in overweight and obese participants with T2DM on shortâterm (three to <12 months) and longâterm (â¥ 12 months) changes in body weight, DBP, HbA1c and LDL cholesterol, and shortâterm constipation. Key details about studies in this comparison, including characteristics of the intervention, population, outcomes and method of synthesis are detailed in the OSIS table (Table 10). Primary outcomes The only primary outcomes reported by the included trials for comparison 4 were change in body weight at three to < 12 months and change in body weight at â¥ 12 months.Â Change in body weight (kg) at three to < 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase may result in little to no difference in change in body weight at six months compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and once for imprecision). The single study reporting change in weight at six months found average weight reductions of 1 kg with the lowâcarbohydrate diet and 0.2 kg with the balancedâcarbohydrate diet. The mean difference in weight reduction between the two diets in this study demonstrated little to no difference at six months (MD â0.80 kg, 95% CI â2.46 to 0.86, 61 participants, 1 RCT,Â lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 4.1). This trial tested diets with a threeâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a threeâmonth weightâmaintenance phase. Change in body weight (kg) at â¥ 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase may result in little to no difference in change in body weight over one to two years compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and once for imprecision). Average changes in weight from baseline over one to two years in the three trials reporting this outcome ranged from a reduction of 2.23 kg to an increase 1.3 kg with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from reductions of 2.17 kg to 1.5 kg with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in weight reduction between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one to two years (MD â0.07 kg, 95% CI â1.31 to 1.17, IÂ² = 0%, 158 participants, 3 RCTs,Â lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 4.2). The shortest of the trials measured change in weight at one year with the diets having a threeâmonth weightâloss phase followed by a nineâmonth weightâreducing phase. The second trial had followâup at 18 months and tested diets with a sixâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a 12âmonth maintenance phase. The third trial had followâup at two years, and tested diets with a threeâmonth weightâreducing followed by a 21âmonth weightâmaintenance phase. All trials had high risk of attrition bias and overall bias, and had diet/food industry funding, precluding sensitivity analyses.Â Secondary outcomes The secondary outcomes reported by the included trials for comparison 4 were change in BMI at three to < 12 months, change in BMI at â¥ 12 months, change in HbA1c, DBP, SBP, LDL and HDL cholesterol, total cholesterol and triglycerides. Â Change in BMI (kg/m2) at three to < 12 months One trial compared these diets using a threeâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a threeâmonth weightâmaintenance phase and reported average BMI reductions from baseline of 0.3 kg/m2 in the lowâcarbohydrate group and 0.01 kg/m2 in the balancedâcarbohydrate group after six months. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in BMI change at six months was â0.29 kg/m2 (95% CI â0.83 to 0.25, 61 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 4.3).Â Change in BMI (kg/m2) at â¥ 12 months The single trial reporting on this outcome in comparison 4 found average BMI reductions from baseline of 0.75 kg/m2 with the lowâcarbohydrate diet and 0.63 kg/m2 with the balanced diet after 18 months (sixâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by 12âmonth weightâmaintenance phase). The mean difference in BMI change at 18 months in this trial was â0.12 kg/m2 (95% CI â0.86 to 0.62, 47 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 4.4). Changes in DBP and SBP (mmHg) at â¥ 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that the evidence is very uncertain about the effect of lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase on change in DBP at one year in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (very lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and twice for imprecision). One trial compared these diets in comparison 4 using a threeâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a nineâmonth maintenance phase, and reported on changes in DBP (MD â0.44 mmHg, 95% CI â4.89 to 4.01, 99 participants, 1 RCT,Â very lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 4.5) and SBPÂ (MD â4.27 mmHg, 95% CI â8.74 to 0.20, 99 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 4.6) at one year. The study reported average DBP increases from a baseline of 0.21 mmHg in the lowâcarbohydrate diet group and of 0.65 mmHg in the balancedâcarbohydrate diet group at one year. For SBP, the study reported an average decrease from baseline of 5.03 mmHg in the lowâcarbohydrate group and 0.76 mmHg in the balancedâcarbohydrate group. Change in HbA1c (%) at 12 months GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase may result in little to no difference in change in HbA1c over one to two years compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and once for imprecision). Average changes in HbA1c from baseline over one to two years in the three trials reporting this outcome ranged from a reduction of 0.39% to an increase of 0.3% with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from a reduction of 0.37% to an increase of 0.4% with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in change in HbA1c between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one to two years (MD 0.02%, 95% CI â0.30 to 0.33, IÂ² = 0%, 160 participants, 3 RCTs,Â lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 4.7). The shortest of the trials measured change in HbA1c at one year with diets having a threeâmonth weightâloss phase followed by a nineâmonth weightâreducing phase. The second trial had followâup at 18 months and tested diets with a sixâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a 12âmonth maintenance phase. The third trial had followâup at two years, and tested diets with a threeâmonth weightâreducing followed by a 21âmonth weightâmaintenance phase. Change in LDL, HDL and total cholesterol and triglycerides (mmol/L) at â¥ 12 months Two trials reported changes in these blood lipids at one to two years. GRADE assessment suggests that lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase may result in little to no difference in change in LDL over one year to 18 months compared to balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets that include a weightâmaintenance phase in overweight and obese participants with T2DM (lowâcertainty evidence, downgraded once for risk of bias and once for imprecision). One trial had followâup at one year with diets having a threeâmonth weightâloss phase followed by a nineâmonth weightâreducing phase. The other trial assessed followâup at 18 months and tested diets with a sixâmonth weightâreducing phase followed by a 12âmonth maintenance phase.Â The metaâanalysis of the mean difference in change in LDL cholesterol between the lowâcarbohydrate and balancedâcarbohydrate diets demonstrated little to no difference at one year to 18 months (MD â0.06 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.26 to 0.13, IÂ² = 0%, 145 participants, 2 RCTs,Â lowâcertainty evidence,Â Analysis 4.8). The two trials reported on HDL cholesterol (MD 0.0 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.07 to 0.08, IÂ² = 0%, 148 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 4.9) and triglycerides (MD â0.06 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.45 to 0.32, IÂ² = 0%, 148 participants, 2 RCTs,Â Analysis 4.11), while only one of the trials reported on total cholesterol at one year (MD â0.16 mmol/L, 95% CI â0.51 to 0.19, 99 participants, 1 RCT,Â Analysis 4.10).Â Average changes in LDL cholesterol over one year to 18 months in the two trials ranged from reductions of 0.2 mmol/L to 0.05 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from a reduction of 0.17 mmol/L to an increase of 0.04 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. For HDL cholesterol, average increases over this period ranged from 0.04 mmol/L to 0.08 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets and from 0.03 mmol/L to 0.08 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate weightâreducing diets. Average changes in total cholesterol at one year reported by the single study ranged from a reduction of 0.15 mmol/L in the lowâcarbohydrate group to an increase of 0.01 mmol/L in the balancedâcarbohydrate group. For triglycerides, average changes over one year to 18 months in the two trials ranged from a reduction of 0.47 mmol/L to an increase of 0.07 mmol/L with lowâcarbohydrate diets and from reductions of 0.3 mmol/L to 0.05 mmol/L with balancedâcarbohydrate diets. Participantâreported adverse effectsÂ Two adverse effects were reported by a single trial in comparison 4 (Watson 2016). This trial reported on anxiety at six months using the 'Anxiety and worry' subscale of the Dâ39 diabetes QoL questionnaire, but did not report sample sizes per group. The mean score in the lowâcarbohydrate diet group was 33.91 (SE 3.55) and in the balanced diet group was 31.43 (SE 3.71). Fatigue at six months was also reported on by this trial using the 'Energy and mobility' subscale of the Dâ39 diabetes QoL questionnaire. The mean score in the lowâcarbohydrate diet group was 22.04 (SE 2.49) and in the balanced diet group was 23.28 (SE 2.61), with no sample sizes being reported per group.
